There is more to getting cancer (and healing from it) than luck, but luck does play a part.  We can't be fully aware of everything we're being exposed to.  That said, I have cancer right now, and the guide offered (at no cost) from Dr. Pete Sulak is helping me.  My choice is to have no more obvious carbs (bread, rice, pasta, potatoes), and no more dairy products.  I am supplementing and using red light therapy.  I learn about the pathology and my stage next Thursday.  I look 10 years younger than the day of my diagnosis....  so I'm wishing that I had done this when I didn't have cancer.

I was diagnosed with stage 2 invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast 10/8/19 and started chemo 11/11/19 with last treatment 3/2/20. I had good days and bad days and having a positive attitude and a great sense of humor got me through it, also having friends and family support me as well. Ended up with a partial mastectomy as the chemo killed the cancer and after healing up from surgery done 4/1/20, I had 5 weeks of radiation that made me tired and getting a rash. As of July 2 of this year, I've been in remission and feeling better.  Still get a little tired at times, but I don't let it bother me, after all I am nearly 66 years old!

Contrary to common belief, cancer is a metabolic disease caused by persistent and prolonged inflammation. Despite treatments like radiotherapy and chemotherapy it resurfaces after certain time in other parts of the body and it is more aggressive and deadly. The underlying condition which is inflammation is never addressed. Inflammation starts with food we eat. It‚Äôs not only most of the foods are inflammatory but also they do not provide sufficient nutrition. Human body requires animal protein and animal fat for proper functioning. Everything else causes inflammation. If you have pain of any kind, difficulty sleeping, lack of energy. These are first signs of inflammation. It is usually followed by anemia. It is very common that at this point people discover they have some form of cancer. Prevent inflammation to stay healthy. You may think this is incoherent rambling that goes against common narrative but there is science to support it. Watch interviews with dr Thomas Seyfried. It‚Äôs easier to blame genetics or other forces instead of accepting fact that in 99% of cases we did this to ourselves following advice from people that have no knowledge of nutrition and how human body works. The cancer numbers are growing with each year. Plus more and more younger people are getting it. 50 years ago it was a rare disease. Now, very often we hear about 1-2 members of the same family to have cancer. Except for genes, the one thing they have in common is food they eat and developed habits. To stay healthy it is imperative to remove inflammation.
My best friend is 48 and now on lifelong chemotherapy. If she doesn‚Äôt she dies. She has a permanent pic line and a colostomy bag

My mom got diagnosed with a rare form of breast cancer in the milk ducts like 4 days before my 16th birthday this year (estimated 1-5 years to live). She's starting chemo soon and just had a surgery to get the chemo port put into her vein. I almost flat out cried knowing she was going to have to get the procedure in the first place when she first told me she was going into the doctor's the next day to get it done. Tbh, I'm kind of scared. Scared of a lot of things. Well, I'm scared of her just dying or being in so much pain and suffering but still "living". It's also kind of ironic that I started getting meds for my depression disorder after she had been diagnosed with cancer for months, and that I'm starting to get myself back together after 5 f*cking years of this disorder and she has to lose her health at the same time. I mostly cope about it all with my music-- whether that be playing my piano or listening to "How to save a life- The Fray" on repeat while crying for 2 hours. Life just kind of sucks, but that's ok, I guess. As long as you learn how to suck right back at it, it gets easier to deal with. :/

I know what you've been going through. I've been battling cancer for over 13 years now. I've had 'hard' chemo for many many months over this time. I chose to control my life instead of the cancer controlling it. I always kept on going to work during my treatments . I was doing chemo once a week for 4 weeks- a 2 week break and   start again over a period of 6 months. I had this regimen 4 times so far. And in between this regimen, I take chemo pills. It's taxing my body but I'm glad to still be here. I know I'll fight it till I die but in the meantime, I'm happy with the life I have. Keep on smiling, and when you have bad days, take in an hour at a time, the next day will be better. And enjoy the moment !! üòäüòäü§óü§ó

For over a decade I've had a sickness the doctors and specialist can quite figure out because it's effect on me vary, but it also leaves me with reduced physical strength and no energy at all, this means that doing anything but sitting still tires me out. Thankfully it's not that bad every day, just most days to a degree, but that simple means that if I'm lucky I might get 6 hours here or half a day and even a day where I feel mostly normal and gets to do thinks because I suddenly do have energy to do stuff and then I take a nap and things flipps around again. It's slowly driving me bonkers, and I can't even begin to explain how frustrating this is, but I'm stuck in it with no way out. It's not fun at all.  All I can do is to take one day at a time and go slow and steady while an unknown sickness slowly kills me. That's my life and has been my life for the past 15 years, but I refuse to wallow much, I rather be reading or watching something good or listening to an audiobook or trying my hands at writing the stories that pop into my head.  Feeling broken like that is more common than many thing, but we who deals with it can only endure. So good luck and I wish you health in the years to come.

I had to do "the red devil" almost six years ago. From what I remember it was actual red. Get lots of rest and share ALL of your side effects with your medical team as they were able to give me meds that helped. I got IV fluids for a couple of day after every round which really helped. At first I was so defeated and I thought I am just going to feel like crap and didn't take good care of myself. Then I realized that while I definitely going to feel sick taking care of myself and accepting support does make a difference. I went from first round not being able to move like AT ALL to being able to move around the house after accepting help and taking care of myself. Wish you well!
Everyone is different when it comes to chemo. I was prepared for nausea and didn't have one day of nausea. What I did have and I am still feeling the effects of (I only stopped chemo a month ago) is the chemo induced neuropathy that is supposed to happen to only 30% of patients.

Hey I didn‚Äôt watch the vid but I‚Äôll leave this here. Cancer cells are ‚Äúaddicted‚Äù to iron. They can make you anemic if you have too many. One thing that you can take to eliminate iron outside your main circulatory supply is to take wormwood with black walnut. Wormwood is a 5,000 year old plant, not a drug; it is much safer than chemotherapy (although combination therapies exist) and results in almost no healthy cell death while outcompeting cancer cells for their growth source (iron). If I got cancer it is the first thing that I would take for two weeks. Also kills viruses. This is advice for family not an ad.

I was got it at 34, lost a boob, as I had two other cancerous cells in my left boob, had my entire lymp system removed from my left side, fortnightly chemo for 4/5 months, I had the red goo which made my nose tingle. Being diagnosed with Breast cancer has been a major loss of money and has caused major problems in my immune system, But when I came across Dr Ogoh on YouTube, after taking his herbal medication I was cured completely of cancer disease. Thanks to Dr Ogoh‚ÜïÔ∏è
I heard you say that you lose a total sense of control and how you're always busy trying to eat and live healthy. Chemotherapy is hard enough as it is, but maybe you will find this information helpful. I'm very interested in diet as a medical doctor in the Netherlands, and I've read up on a study done here in the breast cancer centre in a city called Leiden. They've researched if intermittent fasting has any influence on the effectiveness of chemotherapy in breast cancer patients and preliminary results (in a small patient cohort) show that tumor shrinkage is significantly bigger in the women who fasted the day before receiving chemo. Another study done a while ago followed breast cancer patients for a period of 7 years who fasted during therapy and saw that recurrence rates are much lower in these women compared to the baseline data. Please note that I am no expert on the topic, nor is intermittent fasting as a therapy taken up in any guidelines (yet), you should definitely confer with your oncologist before starting this kind of diet/therapy. I did want to post this message however, because from personal experience with my loved ones I've seen how regaining a bit of control during 'regular' cancer treatment has helped them cope with the whole disease process. A positive, fighting spirit makes up half the treatment success in cancer I've heard say, keep it up!
I throw up so much. Don't feel bad. My husband ex wife takes most of my money. I raised their kids to be strong! Be strong! I choose immuno ve are like you. Immuno was our choice. Chemo took my sister. I don't care about my hair loss.

He counted on my mom to help listen during appointments.  Proud of you Bec, you are a warrior!

Wow Bec you are BEAUTIFUL. And Eamon what a beautiful partner you are. So inspirational you two.
Everything you choose and choose not to show us, we accept. We just want you to have a speedy recovery.
SUPPORT GROUPS ADVICE: have someone you are close to join some online caregivers support groups (Facebook is good). You will learn so much from the caregivers and patients that have gone through this before. So much more than the Drs will ever tell you. Questions you would never think to ask. But don't do that yourself Bec. Not until you are almost through it. Because you will also see all the scary things others have gone through that you probably won't but all that extra possible bad stuff could give you anxiety. So you need someone else to gather that good information but that can weed through the negative stuff being shared. But it's important to know this stuff too so if it happens you know what to expect and if you should panic and ask your Dr right away at 3am or say it's ok this is normal, we can email them in the morning or discuss at the next appointment.   You will do great, it will be hard but you can do this. And be a great inspiration for everyone else at the same time. That's pretty amazing! Both of you are.

Oh, lord, do I remember that cherry Koolaid going into my veins. Wicked stuff‚Äîand I remember the nurse telling me to put the lid down on the toilet when I flushed until I quit peeing pink, because the stuff could become airborne and if it gets on skin it can burn.  A) that‚Äôs creeped me out about keeping my toothbrush in the bathroom ever since, and B) don‚Äôt you wonder about the people who first thought they should shoot something like that into a person‚Äôs vein?  But I‚Äôll tell you‚Äîit is a tried and true treatment.  I had it in 2001, and I‚Äôm cancer-free today.  So hang in there. You will get through this, and you‚Äôll be glad you did it.  And by the way‚Äîthe next treatment might be easier.  Each time it‚Äôs different.  My 2nd and 3rd treatments were actually much easier than the first.  The last one was a little rougher, but it was OK because I knew it WAS the last.    And BTW, I had hair down to my bum when it all started‚Äîlosing it was awful, but in the end, worth it. Just be prepared‚Äîwhen your appearance changes, it makes it all even more real.  You WILL get through it, and be so much more confident in your own strength on the other side.  And Eamon, you take care of yourself too‚Äîand talk to someone about what YOU are dealing with . I‚Äôve been the patient, and I‚Äôve been the loved one supporting the patient.  In some ways the latter is harder‚Äîas the patient I never felt as helpless as I did as the caregiver.  Take time to de-stress every day. Get some rest and do things that you enjoy‚Äîtake breaks when you need to and don‚Äôt feel guilty about it. Self care for you is just as important‚Äîthis is part of being there for Bec. It breaks my heart to see you dealing with this! I was sick about 10 years ago. Diff diagnosis and diff type of treatment but similar sickness. Lost half of my hair. Etc‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know if this will help you but for some reasons baths really helped me with the nausea. I never liked them prior to being sick but for some reason floating in the water really helped. It was the only place the nausea eased up and I would imagine the universe washing my sickness away with the water as I drained the tub. It helped me a lot to visualize the sickness leaving my body. Are you not taking steroids? I had the very exact treatment and if I took my steroids on time before and after treatment, I never got sick.  Everyone is different but it's very dangerous to be vomiting.  Take your steroids on time.  Just an FYI.  Nobody should be sick from chemo if the meds are taken on time.

Hi Bec, have you spoken with your doctor about cold cap therapy during chemo? It enables you to keep your hair instead of shedding your entire head of hair and having to deal with hair loss on top of everything else.
Although it's impossible to pinpoint any habit of her lifestyle that could cause cancer, I would be holding back if I didn't say that her vegan diet may be a part of what caused this. Perhaps she eats the same thing for most of her calories and as a result doesn't have a broad enough diet to prevent deficiencies. People haven't been vegan for very long and this could mess up her biology as a human. While it is an ethical attempt to be vegan, it may not be the right way for humans to live a long life. Then again there may be vegans who live long healthy lives, and this jumps out to me as something that she could change her life. Best of luck

Just sharing a perspective -  from a metaphysical anatomy angle, cancer is related to "a fear of loosing control". The area/organ in which cancer unfolds point us towards the type of fears we need to work on. Woking on the fear may release the "stuck" energies and help you rewire the way your energy is flowing in you body. "Bad luck" or "genetic predisposition" can be scary labels (and not real answers in my humble opinion) that generate impotence becase "what can I do about that? right?". There is more to our emotional and psychomental anatomy that influences how our genetic heritage "expresses" itself. They say more cancer is related to genetic expression rather than predisposition. in other words, by working on the subtle energies that precede the physicality of the cancer we can begin to adjust the way our genes express within the life we create. I was a young girl when I watched one of my aunts go through stomach cancer, and then watching my great aunt painfully go through chemo for stage 4 ovarian cancer. Finding this ever growing positive research on the guided use of medicinal psilocybin, mycelium, and other magical healing properties of mushrooms that aren't just psychedelic and can be incorporated into cooking. The recorded effects are just absolutely remarkable as there are hundreds of different types of mushrooms with many different types of medicinal benefits to humans. I just really wanted to share this information with you, if you guys are ever in the mood, I really suggest watching this documentary "Fantastic Fungi" on Netflix, as well as checking out the amazing research on the extraordinary healing properties of mushrooms in cancer patients who are also undergoing cancer treatment, I'm dropping some links below for you guys.  https://www.mdanderson.org/cancerwise/can-medicinal-mushrooms-help-during-cancer-treatment.h00-159460056.html#:~:text=Some%20studies%20show%20mushrooms%20boost,is%20helpful%20for%20cancer%20patients.%E2%80%9D  https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/cam/patient/mushrooms-pdq  https://stramcenter.com/blog/blog-detail/mushrooms-breast-cancer-support/  Google Scholar will give you guys direct scholarly research articles from any type of academic journals, and typing in keywords such as; mushrooms/breast cancer/effects/ and a geographical location will narrow or broaden your searches. My best friend lived a healthy lifestyle too yet came down with a small cell sarcoma in his left hamstring.  His doctors used chemo to try and kill the cancer. When it was determined to be85 to 90 percent killed, they surgically removed the rest of it. During his chemo, he was given Nulasta to restore white blood cell count. His bones always ached for a couple days but it worked well. He beat his cancer but three years later, cancer was found in his right lung, middle lobe. That was surgically removed and he just passed his 1 year scan, no new issues. He's recovered nicely. Everyone I know has beaten cancer. Doctors are able to amazing things these days. Best wishes and May God Bless...

Eamon: Thank you for letting us watch all the caring you are providing Bec.  I was in Bec‚Äôs place 4.5 years ago, and although I thanked my husband all the time, your videos give me another perspective of the stress this causes you too. I didn‚Äôtperceive the toll on my husband, probably because I was feeling so sick.    Bec: You are strong, you have awesome support from family and friends. It is a long road, but you will get through this.  Thank you for sharing your struggles.  My advice is, figure out when chemo is over.  You will have 2-4 weeks before surgery.  Take a week vacation to a place where you are not doing all the work, stay in a hotel, if your want.  This will be the time when you will be feeling well, with no pain, no sickness and traveling will be so awesome. Make some memories.  I was able to vacation with my husband and 9 year old because it ended up working out (chemo was delayed a week due to illness) that chemo ended before my son‚Äôs spring break, and surgery did not happen until after his spring break.  We went to Utah in April and visited many of the national parks, and hiked in them.  I never would have thought of this except I had already started planning the trip before  I was diagnosed.  I asked the oncology nurse if I should cancel our plans.  She said don‚Äôt cancel yet, things may work out.  And only because the extension of my chemo by a week, we were able to keep our plans for this vacation.   Thinking about you, and sending e-strength.

Dogs can sense cancer and it was the main reason why my mom went to the doctor to get her lump checked coz my dog was acting strange around her. My dog was with her the whole way through and always was more gentle and helpful for my mom in her toughest times. Ons knows what you are going through and even if u foster dogs in the future they will never know what u have went through. Ons seems friendly with other dogs so you can always foster more dogs in the future. I have friends who foster dogs and sometimes when they want to keep one, they usually will be like well we want to help as many dogs as possible and we can't adopt all the dogs we foster and I tell this to a lot of people as well. From a cancer Sister üéÄ I literally feel you. At the end of 2020, I was told, "You have Breast Cancer."  2021 was full of a lot of unknown and first things. I remember thinking about what I did wrong; I tried to have a healthy life and be active. Don't torture yourself; this is not your fault. In my case, I had a genetic test done, and I happened to be the first in my generation üôÉ. With the chemo, try to find your body's rhythm for me the weekend after chemo was bad, I had to sleep and rest, and the second week was better I'll use my energy to get things done. But listen to your body. Don't feel bad for sleeping, and don't feel bad for not being "productive" REST. Your body is fighting one of the biggest fights in your life right now.
I wanted to tell you about Coriolus versicolor, the most studied anti cancer mushroom, very  effective against breast cancer, and also mitigates the side effects of chemotherapy.  Mushroom Science out of OR is a great company. A family member with poor prognosis is alive 10 years later thanks to this. I‚Äôm so glad you have each other
Bec, I just wanted to let you know I'm praying for you.  And Eamon, I can relate to what you are feeling for Bec.  My family has been riddled with various cancers.  I have come to believe that yes many cancers are caused by where you live, what you eat, what you put into your body, where you work & how you live your life. But some cancers I feel are like a virus or germs that you "catch".  If your body can fight it & kill it, you have no clue about it.  If your body is unable to fight & kill it, then you catch it and it develops into cancer of some kind.  Sounds like a child's mind's viewing but I really believe it.  So Bec please don't blame yourself or keep asking, "what could I have done or not done right?"  You are young, strong and healthy.  You WILL beat this!  My prayers & support are with you in this trying time.
‚ù§Ô∏èüôèüçÄ Please get some WATERMELON before your next chemotherapy.  Have it on hand and try it.  It was the only thing that tasted good to me during chemotx and it actually made me feel better too.  Please try it, I have recommended to lots of people who say it helped so much.  It will be worth the effort even if you have to hunt for it (I know it is not in season in Canada.).  Much love and best wishes to you from a 61 year old, 42 year cancer survivor.  You will look back on this one day and be well!  You both and all your family are lovely people.  It warms my heart to watch you and the love you share. Note: prior to radiation ask the doctors advice for timing of eating watermelon or tomatoes since they both contain lycopene which is a protection against and treatment for sunburn.  Might not want to have it day of or day after, but radiology oncologist should know the timing.

Just had my first AC treatment 1 week ago today.  I didn't start this journey that healthy food and exercise wise, so I'm having to change my eating habits during this process.  I don't think I was that successful at that the first week.  It was a struggle to find something that I could keep down the first few days, and afterwards nothing quite tasted the same. Food has started to taste the same again, but it's hard to drink water, not because of the taste but because it makes me feel nauseous.  I plan to get better at going  for walks and getting healthier food and drinks in going forward.  Symptom wise, I've experienced being tired as well as nausea and dry mouth.  The actual chemo infusion part wasn't bad, but I'm still not looking forward to going back.  Thanks for posting your journey.  As always saying prayers that we alll make it through this and find ourselves stronger and healthier when it's all over (and cancer free for life).
My mother had breast cancer back in the stone age of medicine. There was no radiation of chemo - they removed her breast and gave her some kind of strong pills to take and then she waited as the years went by praying that it would not come back - and after 5 years, her doctor told her that she did not have to worry anymore. In the meantime, she got fitted with a prosthesis so she'd look good in a dress again. Mom lived to be 93 before she passed with stomach and colon cancer. It seems like on average, more people die from cancer than anything else - could it be from all the preservatives we consume? I suspect so.... It goes without saying, that I'll be praying for you Bec, and your wonderful patient husband, Eamon. God bless you both.

Best wishes on your journey. I did chemo for 12 weeks starting in Jan 2021 and did Herceptin every 3 weeks from Jan-Dec 2021. My husband couldn't go as well and it tortured him to not be there with me. Stupid COVID!!!!!  But the oncology nurses were absolutely wonderful and took great care of me. The chairs were heated, reclined and had massagers, there were heated blankets, internet access and my own little TV in a curtained cubicle was surprisingly relaxing. They provided drinks and snacks as well -  I just tried to relax. They told me to ask if I needed anything - so if you need something - say something - they can usually accommodate. Hang in there - you can do it!

You've got this. My mom lives a very similar lifestyle, works out every day, eats organic, avoids single use plastics. She developed breast cancer and then after, developed breast implant illness due to an undiagnosed autoimmune disorder (hashimotos). She is doing amazing, advocating for women, attempting to ensure the health professionals who work with women take our complaints and concerns seriously. We as a family try to support her by taking our health seriously, going to the doctor even when it's scary.   Her biggest recommendations for people going through it are arnica for swelling/bruising and to aid in healing (actually prescribed by her surgeon), a breast surgery pillow (we sewed one at home), cozy socks, a good show, and a lot of grace. No one asks for this but you have the opportunity to help so many by sharing. Thank you and sending so many healing thoughts.

PLEASE read the Cancer Code by Dr. Jason Fung. Find out if your cancer feeds on sugar. If it does, STAY away from carbs, which means fruits and most veggies as they break down into sugars. Instead, eat organic meats, eggs, and green cruciferous veggies only.  Eating fruits and veggies because they break down into sugars can be absolutely the wrong thing to do as some cancers thrive on that. To starve them, you need to eat healthy fats. like pressed from avocado, coconut, and butter.

Hi Eamon and Bec, i just want you to know Bec, that Im sorry to hear you are dealing with cancer and i hope you recover very soon.  My mother inlaw had breast cancer and among the things that helped speed up her recovery were these two matters.  1: Starve the cancer cells: Eliminate all animal protein from your diet (fish, milk, meat, eggs etc.) 2: Prevent cell damage: At sunset (bedtime) you should go to sleep in a room with no artificial lighting on or electronic devices.  Stay positive and take each day as it comes, live life in the moment and dont allow the cancer to get you down. I know thats easy for me to say, but believe me having a positive state of mind helps your body to fight and withstand as much as possible, whatever the ailment.
I want you to know that Jesus loves you and he can heal you from all sickness. I don't know if you know him but pray to the Lord Jesus Christ, ask for healing, read his word which can not only bring healing to your physical body but also renew your mind. Dear Bec...and of course dear Eamon...I know so many are writing to you. I just want you to know that the thing I felt grateful for, as you reminded us to be in the video, is you. You just have such a sweet spirit and so much love. Your joy, and your "together joy," have blessed us all for several years now. It's our joy and our privilege to join you in this journey and cheer you on in the fight. To give you a big horseshoe in your boxing glove today in that fight, let me just tell you the short version of my sister's journey with cancer. She was diagnosed with the 2nd to last stage of ovarian cancer, stage 3c. It's staged differently than others, with 4 being the last (no letters). She was in very difficult odds, and had a large abdominal surgery, three types of chemo. After 18 months of remission (good sign with ovarian to go that long), she came out of remission--and they beat it back in. She had prayer in every church in town. :) She committed herself to God and healthy eating and continued to work with a doctor she had chosen and trusted. She had fun with the most beautiful wigs! Long story short, she is back in remission and has been there ever since. That was back in 2008! Her original diagnosis was in 2006, recurrence in 2008, and has been cancer-free ever since...14 more beautiful years and she is enjoying it more because of the wisdom gained. She is cancer-free today (and still avoiding excess iron and iron skillets). I'm grateful every day for my sister, her spirit, her fight, and her victories--over fear and over dread--you do it scared when necessary and it still works. :)  Eamon...I so feel with you...felt that empty feeling as you had to watch her walk away to treatment while you stood watching, and walked back to the vehicle by yourself...I so felt that! Better days are ahead. -*-Better Days Are Ahead!-*- !!! Thank you for all the joyful and meaningful and heart-filled videos. Without having met you in person, I've met your spirits, and I love you guys. Like many others, I'm with you in the journey. "In the morning, there comes joy." Hugs and much love to you.-- Mary

It really sucks when you've done everything you could do be healthy and stuff just goes wrong. So much of how we age and our risk for diseases is unfortunately dependent on genetics, and only partially life choice influence many of these things. Some people smoke and drink a ton their whole lives, never get cancer.
I have stage 4 ER PR positive breast cancer. The "red devil" is tough but they have so many meds that keep the nausea somewhat controlled. There is only one way to get through and that is one day at a time & lots of rest. Everything gets dry so eye drops and saline nose spray are also handy. Hang in there, the 6 months go faster than you think

Please consider working with a flower essence practitioner to support both of you emotionally. Dis-ease often manifests out of emotional trauma, and it was about a year ago you lost your beloved friend, Lee. And of course both of you are dealing with the trauma of the diagnosis. There are several essence companies in Canada. I'm most familiar with Pacific Essences in B.C., and if you do a search on flower essences in Canada you will find lots of possibilities. Also, a friend of mine, many years ago, was diagnosed with breast cancer and during chemo, she put an ice pack on her head during the treatments. She didn't lose her hair. Hope that might work for you. Prayers and healing for both of you as you move through this. I so honor your courage in sharing your story.
Dear Bec, the positive attitude with which you are facing this most difficult challenge in your life thus far is not only brave and commendable, but it will serve you well in the months ahead. And how wonderful that you have such a giving and supportive partner in Eamon. It's a blessing. We went through breast cancer in our home as well and it was a scary time. Like you, my partner had no family history, she's vegetarian, non-smoker, etc., etc., and yet there we were. But we are now 10 years out, thank goodness and knock on wood, and she's healthy. So just keep thinking positive thoughts as you are, but also allow yourself to not feel like yourself in the months ahead. This tiredness that you're feeling is only going to progress as you continue your treatments. My partner used to tell me she felt like she got hit by a truck. So be kind to yourself and know that it is part of the process and will be for some time.  And Eamon, you too need to be kind to yourself and ask for help when you need it. You need to find a way to process your feelings of helplessness and fear of the unknown. Sometimes it's getting out for a walk to clear your head, maybe go for a beer with a friend, or a phone call to a family member to discuss how you're feeling. Because as the caregiver you feel like you have to be strong for your partner that is sick and therefore not show that you too are scared and going through this. And your partner, Bec, will be getting all of the attention from everyone because she's the one that is sick, and that's natural. But you're going through it too. So please allow yourself to be vulnerable and share your feelings with a friend or family member.¬†  And I promise you this, when you get through this, and you will get through this, you will be even stronger as a couple. I'm sending you both lots of healing positive energy.

I think it is most excellent that you guys are documenting this part of your lives. Both my wife and I both have dealt with cancer and are currently cancer free (knock wood).  At our age (early 70‚Äôs) our life is full of OMG what is next on health challenges.  With your age group and your life style getting cancer seems extremely unfair.  But your guys are providing an important message‚Ä¶. live is not always a bowl of cherries, not even a box of chocolates,  Its more like a bag of jelly bellies that have dirt, rotten eggs, snot flavored jelly beans in the mix of good ones.  So the message is that shit can happen anytime to anyone. so never take good times for granted.  The next lesson that I am sure you will be showing us is that even in the darkest times there are brilliant glimmers of happiness and major epiphanies.  This battle I am sure is going to greatly deepen your love and understanding for and from Eamon, your family, and your friends. So hang in there.  BTW when my wife had breast cancer we spent a LOT of time feeling sad with spontaneous crying sessions.  I felt that I had to do something to kick us out of the that cycle.  I am not that religious but swear a voice from somewhere in my head said ‚Äúget a puppy‚Äù (our previous dog had died the month before).  So we got one and suddenly THAT is was became what we thought and talked about.  So getting that dog of yours was Brilliant if I must says so.
As a caregiver sitting and waiting for chemo to finish, this gave me so much hope & faith in the future. Hugs from Missouri üíì

You probably already do this given your holistic lifestyle, but if not, please practice meditation & positive visualization - I was diagnosed with a rare autoimmune disease 8 years ago that attacked my nerves (similar to MS but not many treatments available) I was unable to walk fo approximately 3 months and was initially told that it would just be progressive to complete disability as it attacked all my peripheral nerves.  The only thing that kept me alive was not wanting to rehome my dog before I died.  I kept visualizing running with him in the fields around my home, it brought me so much comfort & faith.  Treatment by my incredible neurologists has me currently in complete remission (8 years & going) but I think the visualization also helped (there is evidence based research on visualization and improving athletic performance).  You will make it through this!  Your comment about sleep/rest really hits home with me also - I had no choice but to sleep & rest because I could barely move/had no energy @ my worst, but I think going through that helped to increase my patience and live more in the moment....I hope it has the same effect for you.

a few things about nutrition (from someone who studies nutritional medicine): a diet healthy for healthy people isn't necessarily healthy for someone with cancer, so (and i'm sure you do) please work with a certified nutritionist to make sure you don't take additional antioxidants during radiotherapy, up your fat intake and all that. and just so you know (in case you didn't): oversupply of b vitamins has been linked with cancer, so please make sure you only supplement when you absolutely need to. i'm pretty sure the way you and eamon eat you don't need to unless you're travelling because you're already eating lots of grains and veggies etc.. b12 for sure and if you feel the need you can get tested for other vitamins, but pleaaase don't supplement when there's no need! some vitamins can do a lot of harm when overdosed and with your vegan diet you're getting enough of most of the things in AG1. I don't blame AG for this, for sure, I just want you to be careful with possibly getting too many of some micronutrients and be aware that having cancer changes your physical needs drastically and what was healthy before might now not be. Sending you alll the love and good energy to get better soon. I know you will beat this cancer like you have beaten so many things before.

I fell sick with flu like symptoms and one thing lead to another causing me to check into the emerg on December 24. 2021. Just typing or saying the word brings tears to my eyes. Here I lay in Ottawa at 1:42am after a radical nephrectomy performed just hours ago. This emotional roller coaster is something I wish nobody ever has to experience. Hey Bec, I am so sorry to hear of your news, I am praying for a healthy recovery. I am studying natural medicine and I was wondering if you wear deodorant. The mainstream deodorants contain aluminium. Not only can aluminium be carcinogenic but a lot of breast cancers start in the lymph nodes in the armpit. Also sweating is necessary to release toxins and prevent excess build up. So no deo and try saunas to help sweat out the chemo :) Also Lumps in the breast according to louise L hay is: "A refusal to nourish the self. Don‚Äôt worry about tomorrow what your not doing just concentrate on the here and now. Forget about any diets. You have to eat what ever you crave. Some of friends found high carb foods helped with the energy levels. But you eat what‚Äôs good for u. Most importantly stay hydrated. Water, Gatorade , anything with electrolyte. You can dehydrated very easily. Stay away from people there germs are your worst nightmare. I know 5 months is a long time right now but think of it as 5 months of the rest of your life. Oh my gosh .....Im so so so  sorry to see this ....my love to you  ......I was diagnosed 2013 started my neoadjuvant chemo  tx in 2014....been on and off chemo since then stage 4 now.......but still here. üôÇ And the exercise.... the healthy diet... the low stress happy life ...i did it all.....i was a raw eater no sugar no beer.. wine or alcohol  no smoking .... Exercising like mad ....beaches ...happiness..sunshine...EVERYTHING thats supposed to prevent this crap....but .... Its just luck of the draw.... Remember take things as slowly as you need to ....get outside on the warm  sunny days even if you are bundled up not feeling too well ....even being outside 5 min in the sun ... can help ...  Adriamycin /Cytoxin AC .....MAKE SURE YOU KEEP YOUR MOUTH COLD....before and as they push the devil....and all day after that too....chemo day cold or cool drinks and foods ...avocado water etc etc avoid a few mouth issues.... DRINK WATER LIKE MAD A FEW DAYS BEFORE ...DAY OF AND AS MUCH AS YOU CAN AFTER!!! Make sure the premeds are IV and cover your needs ...at the least Aloxi Emend Zofran Dexamethasone Pepcid etc benadryl etc  MAKE SURE YOU ASK IF TAKING ANTIOXIDANTS IS ALLOWED( those fancy drinks or vitamins and nuts etc )  as they can negate some of the "liquid sunshine" benefits ....  May the sun shine on you .....you will make it through this .....and don't be afraid to call your nurse  asap for ANY ISSUES  ps head will feel like a too tight pony tail......when its gonna fall ....just cut a bob now then cut shorter as you go  I just had chemo monday ...my 5th line ....so 5th drug ive been on .....ill feel.ok mon tues and wed....then thurs the premeds wear off....pajamas for 7 more days after that ...but then it starts to get a little better  Be proud .....this is so hard .....its going to be ok

Its been 21 years and 10 months since my first chemo of A/C and I remember being so very anxious.  I have helped many with information for their journey, because I believe 'Knowledge is Power.'  You are sharing soooo much power with others!  I offer: don't look at it as 5 months..take a week at a time.  A treatment at a time.  After the second treatment I used to call day 3 "The Pit" Day.  I really was not sure I would get better, but, I always crawled out of that pit. You will, too!  You are strong going into this so you are going to make it, but keep your energy expectations low.  ALLOW yourself rest.  One of my favorite song in 2000 when I went through my chemo was Barbara Streisand The Main Event/Fight.  It was a weird little movie about boxing, but I would imagine little boxing gloves in my veins punching out the bad cells...fight, fight fight!  And they were so busy fighting, I was pooped!  Go with it!  You are blessed to have a healthy body going into it.  Love surrounds you.  Dogs ALWAYS know and Oso sure loves you!  Take his energy of love to help you through!  And ZOFRAN! Best anti-nausea pill EVER and it is still out there!  Allow yourself PIT DAYS.  You will come out of it.  You got this. One treatment at a time.

In my Research I've come up with a possible cause... At our birth....Mom's Microorganism fill our Lymph nodes APPENDIX TONSILS amount other storage.... As we live Life we use Antibiotics that empty our micro reserve's..... & They fill with Fungus that our Immune system tries to force OUT.... Sometimes the Breast is the Closest way OUT.... & It maybe Stuck = Breast Cancer.... Good Luck....
I am so sorry you are going through this.  17 years ago I started walking the path you find yourself on today.  I understand how life has completely changed, and that every morning you wake up, the day is coloured by the fact you have cancer.   If you react to that fact with a strong heart, half the battle will be over.  May I share a couple of really important things that I wished that I knew way back when? Sometimes doctor's speak in percentages when discussing why option #1 may be better than option #2.  Try to ensure each percentage discussed is absolute.  For example....h results of a study show 20% of people respond positively to XYZ.  But, you need to know if that number is absolute (20 people out of every 100) and not relative (1 out of 5).  Next, the amounts of drugs you'll be given, i.e. chemo, are calculated by your physical body mass only.  But how you'll feel will be more connected to how fast or slow you metabolize medication.  I quit my chemo after two sessions because I metabolize medication very slowly vand I was overweight at the time.  It's great to see you have set priorities that bring you joy....having a walk and a hug.  Safeguard your immune system and your quality of life.  The whole point of treatment is to become cancer free for the rest of your life.  And not to suffer from serious side effects from drugs.  I too had estrogen receptor positive breast cancer, and was almost given a taxane in my chemo cocktail.  But two days prior, I was reading a study from a cancer institute saying taxanes aren't effective for estrogen receptor positive cancer.  When I brought this up with my oncologist, she was comfortable leaving it out.  But if I'd not done my homework I would have received this chemo.  It happens to have the most serious side effects that can last a long time.  Listen to your body....and your intuition.  You'll be amazed at how much you'll benefit from this.   Good luck to you both!!!
Thank you so much for sharing your journey. I can't tell you how helpful it is to hear from someone going through a similar serious health journey. It's great to hear the thoughts that run through your mind and how you are dealing with all of the emotions and allowing yourself to rest and heal. I think it's even harder for someone as young as you.   You are used to relying on your body and all the sudden  now you can't. That is a tough realization in it's self.   My prayers are with you, we are strong women and we can do this!  I've found hope in looking at what I still have.   Somedays I can't walk well but that means I can cuddle my dogs and binge watch Netflix.   I've taught myself to knit,  crochet and now diamond painting!   I find creating gives me so much joy!   Praying you find a place of peace and comfort.

He is also perfect in Justice, meaning, he will bring EVERY sin to light. The punishment for our sin is death, and Hell; a place of Eternal Fire, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth .  Fortunately God is also perfect in Love; so 2000 years ago, he left his throne in heaven, and came to earth as a man named Jesus Christ. While here, he lived a perfectly righteous life, only to take the punishment that We deserved; Our sinless creator became our sin, and endured a gruesome death on a cross. In doing so, his blood was shed to wash us clean of our transgressions . Right before he died, he said ‚Äòit is finished‚Äô .. meaning, the debt for our sins has been paid in full. And on the third day, he defeated death and rose from the grave. So now, we can go free from the wrath of God‚Äôs judgement not by earning it, but rather, as a free gift of grace ..  Except gifts can be either accepted or rejected. So this is what you must do in response ;   Humbly admit to God that you have sinned against him. If you do so sincerely, God will grant you a new heart which no longer finds comfort in sin, but instead desires to read and obey his word, the holy bible. Chemotherapy gives you a 1% chance of survival. Google it if you don't believe me. All you are doing is making the last days of your life riddled with illness. Cut out the Chemo and bring in the fruits and veggies. Overload your diet with nutrition. If it's not too late it'll cure the cancer. If it is too late, You'll die. So why spend your last days being ill?
It truly is overwhelming to get a diagnosis and then all the stuff that comes with it. It affects you each individually and as a couple. I am a 9 1/2 yr survivor of breast cancer. The big picture of chemo, surgery, radiation...it was alot to process. So I had to break it down and concentrate not just on each chemo session but just getting through each day! And in each day we celebrated each little victory..whatever it was, we found something to celebrate each day. If nothing got worse, that was a little victory! But each day we remembered to be grateful for each other,  my super girl power medical team made up of amazing women! I know you have the courage and the strength to make it through all of it! All of a sudden you find yourself part of an amazing community and meet others going through their journey. Embrace those connections as we all become sisters of the heart !‚ù§

Hey Bec :) At the very start when you're talking about all the things you "do right", I just wanted you to know, I'm certain it made a difference - i went plant based during and because of cancer (cervical cancer from 21 years old) and it improved me greatly and improved by progress away from cancer - i truly believe that if i stayed vegetarian i would have gotten a lot sicker and been sicker for a lot longer. I know its tough and you ask yourself why when you are otherwise so healthy but i really believe that i would have been so much sicker if i hadn't have already been healthy and happy and at the least vegetarian (with a dairy allergy, so almost vegan! :) )... I didnt recieve treatment until i was 24 and i do believe i wouldnt have even made it that far if i wasnt already looking after my bod and heart!      I'm certain this is the case for you too as you seem textbook happy and have such a wonderful soul, so please don't blame yourself :)   p.s. I know its not the same cancer; treatment etc and i dont want to give false hope, rather to know that it isn't impossble... I am now 32, still not yet able to say im in remission, but I am 26 weeks pregnant with our first baby, a little boy <3   So very much love xxxxxxx

You are starting with the right attitude.  I went through chemo for breast cancer from June to November 2020.  And you mentioned ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù.  It may sound strange but I enjoyed chemo as I had to go by myself because of COVID (even though I would have wanted to go by myself anyhow). I felt throughout chemo that I had control as I was ‚Äúdoing chemo‚Äù if that makes ANY kind of sense.   My biggest recommendation‚Ä¶ stay hydrated (I drank a solid 80 oz a day during chemo because I watched another lady on YouTube who said it helped her). You might only be able to eat chocolate foods like youhoo chocolate drink, maybe even thing you have never eaten before
The whole issue with thinking that your personal health comes down *only* to healthy living is so damaging. I know that only few people actually believes this wholeheartedly, but it is very easy to get sucked into that mentality in todays wellness/health culture. It puts pressure on us that are sick - like you must do something wrong or you wouldn‚Äôt be sick (which is ridiculous but easy to feel and also to judge people because it runs as an undercurrent under so many health blogs/content). It is good to optimize your chances of being healthy by eating right etc. but this belief system is so damaging and I wish people would stop. Sometimes life just throws a bucket of crap at you and nothing you did caused it. I have been chronically ill for half my life and spend 80 % of my time in bed and have to use a wheelchair. I promise you that with time you get sort of used to being sick and it won‚Äôt feel so bad. Happiness is not dependent on good health. But I hope that you get well super quickly! üíï

Hi Guys!! Most of what manifests in the body as dis-ease or any other ailment comes from the unconscious... its our bodies trying to communicate with us and the physical is the most in your face.. plus, and I'm sure many will challenge this, it has both a reason for existing and a purpose thus its origins are of a spiritual nature so it wouldn't have mattered if you drank 20,000 green juices for example, it would have happened anyway... another thing, being "positive" will NOT help in situations like yours... its coming from the same place that manifested this dis-ease... the truth is more important than any label... if you feel like shit indulge it for example and give it your attention and allow it to be felt and heard... do the same for all of those most trying moments!!... anyway, hang in there, there is much to learn down this rabbit hole!!

17 years as a chemo Nurse: Eat everything, High protein food well cooked. Marijuana can help with nausea and eating. Eat anything you want you need calories to fight cancer. Don't go to support meetings to many negative vibes. See about zometa to protect your bones. Vitamin C infusions may help. You may have to get them from an infusion center/ Myers cocktail also. IF your HER 2, Keytruda and Herceptin later treatment. Definitely do immediate reconstruction. Stay away from negative people!!. Your guys job is to step in when anyone wants to tell you their  stories/ almost always something negative. If they will not stop the best is to ask them to help out by cleaning up the dog poop. The best help is helping clean your place while your getting treatment, cooking home made dinners, simple things. A simple thing have a small piece of dark chocolate 30-45 minutes before treatment, it taste good, and it helps the tumors uptake of the chemo, cancer loves sugar so the tumor cells will take the chemo upload at a higher rate. DO what the doctor says!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! All my Best Robert G.

My mom was diagnosed with stage 4 triple negative breast cancer last summer. I‚Äôve been to all her appointments, chemo treatment, surgeries etc. As a 28 year old woman, I have such a bigger fear of breast cancer now. What I‚Äôve learned through all this is that the fear of the unknown is worse than the fear of truth. That fear can eat you up, so we have had to learn that the answer is to keep moving. We grieve when we get bad news then we keep moving. We praise God when we get good news, then we keep moving. I‚Äôm praying for your recovery and for the journey ahead.

Bec I went through almost the exact cancer diagnosis 2.5 years ago just a short distance from Kingston. It is up to each Oncologist and Surgeon as to their treatment plan but I was surprised to hear your surgery wasn't first like mine. My tumor was discovered 1mm from from chest wall during a mammogram so perhaps because it was in a dangerous location as the cells could escape through my chest wall.  I will say that I was given multiple (2 different) anti-nausea meds and they always questioned if I had any nausea. I was told from the get-go that it's important I don't suffer from nausea or obviously throw up. I never got sick. Please ask your doctors about getting another med and make sure you're taking the meds. You shouldn't feel anything different. I was on the red devil as well and was on it for 12 weeks with radiation at the end. Radiation just buy a ivory bar soap and a really really good lotion, I was recommended to use Eucerin. It worked great. My home nurse made me wash my radiation area well with Ivory Bar soap to keep it very clean. That helped a lot because I was getting a skin infection until I started washing the area.   I am now going every 8 weeks to get my radiation tattoos removed! üòÅ   PS I chose a lumpectomy. Unfortunately after my surgery the tumor was sent for the OncotypeDX test and I wasn't given the best outcome as well my Gene testing proved to show I have the BRCA gene. I am fine and I've done everything possible to stay health. üëçüèª
Makes me sad but I'm still sending happy thoughts that this sunshine works and you kick this cancer in the butt!! Eamon your the best keep up the great support!!
Best of luck to you both.   üôèüèªüôèüèª‚ù§Ô∏è

I‚Äôm a pharmacy technician at a hospital in Ontario. My job is to mix chemo drugs for patients just like you. I wanted to thank you for sharing your journey, so I can see the effects my job has on patients like you. Unfortunately my job is in the background of every patients journey and we see your names, diagnosis, medication and dose to be administered and your patient number. In the chemo room, we only refer to patient by there name because a person isn‚Äôt a number or defined by their diagnoses. We think about everybody‚Äôs safety and health whether it‚Äôs scrubbing and gowning up before mixing or wiping down and bagging the iv bags after mixing‚Ä¶everyone of you are in our thoughts‚Ä¶each individual person. I am so sorry you have to go through this <3. As a Triple Negative BC survivor myself (diagnosed in 2018 and currently in remission), I can tell you from my own experience that the initial waiting phase (i.e. period between diagnosis to first treatment) was mentally the hardest for me and then everything became slowly better once the treatment commenced. Few tips and tricks from my own 16 rounds of ACT chemo journey: stay hydrated and eat lots of fiber (chemo constipation is a b#$@&), stay away from those cancer muggles (especially those who give stupid medical advice or diet recommendations), don't feel bad about taking time off to rest and heal and be your own fierce advocate <3. You've got this!

A long time ago I went vegan because I thought it would prevent cancer, I then learned through a lot of information through many sources and knowledgeable people that it‚Äôs actually kind of the opposite. the sugars in plants cause cancer too I do believe. When people are not on a plant based diet they still don‚Äôt eat ‚Äúright‚Äù and that‚Äôs why they say plant based diets can prevent cancer, although it‚Äôs not necessarily true at all that‚Äôs not how it works ..  you should try to look into the keto diet. That‚Äôs probably the healthiest diet out there in my opinion. You need meat! We all do! I used to be vegan like I said, for all the same reasons and more. Being vegan isn‚Äôt all there is to keeping yourself perfectly healthy though. I contemplated keeping this to myself because I know it‚Äôs controversial but I feel like the vegan diet is widely misconstrued so I hope my words open you to the idea of looking deeper into other diets. I wish you health and happiness bec <3 you got this. You‚Äôre amazing.

Your lifestyle is so healthy that it does seem hard to understand. My first thought was the tofu you eat. Soy based food has links to breast cancer from the estrogenic chemicals known as isoflavones. The research on this is conflicting, with some saying it can be protective and others saying it can cause cancer. Please look into Frankincense essential oil for its cancer fighting properties.

CANCER has no rules. It will come for anyone. She‚Äôs a bitsh straight from HELL. I always said I won‚Äôt get cancer. It‚Äôs not even in my family, except my uncle. He smoked since he was 12 and got lung cancer. I was out of town and a gallbladder attack sent me to the ER. They figured out the gallbladder but things weren‚Äôt right. So ,I was admitted to the hospital. They finally figured out I had kidney cancer around 9 pm. I had a 17 and 19 year old daughters at home. My surgery was scheduled for 6am. Possibly saying goodbye to them over the phone was horrible. I survived. Thankfully.... You get to fight. And have an amazing supportive family around you. It‚Äôs ok to feel angry, sad, happy etc.....Feel it and keep fighting. People you don‚Äôt even know are rooting for you. You guys have helped me through the death of my daughter. HI! I feel you 100, im a stage 4 tongue cancer survivor - and all they told me was it was bad luck. I don't smoke, rarely drink and HPV negative - i had no reason to get cancer and i did. After surgery, losing half my tongue plus chemo and radiation - i am not 5 years post!! i know when you're in the middle of it all it seems so dark and daunting; but remember everything you did before you were diagnosed is what will keep your body resilient while you're in treatment.  I know you both are so active - but the beggest gift you can give to yourselves right now is grace.  Grace on the days your too tired to do anything but lay around, grace on the days your too sick to eat and can barely have tea, and grace on the days where you feel like giving up.  Trust the process, trust in your body.  As odd as it sounds everytime i went into treatment i sent my cancer love - i would say "l love you, and thank you for showing up in my life to show me a lesson i currently don't understand, but it's time for you to go you're no longer welcome in my space".  I am sending you so much healing vibes and truly am available to chat with, i know our cancers are different - but please know you're not alone in everything you both are feeling. <3

The "why me" questions never go away... When you are first diagnosed you ask why me? What did I do to deserve this illness? Why am I being punished? What could I have done differently?... Once you beat it you ask why me? Why am I the one to survive when so many lose their battle? As a stage 4 pediatric cancer survivor I struggle with the survivor's guilt every day. I see little ones earning their wings and would do anything to trade places. When my mom was diagnosed with breast cancer over a decade ago all of the fear and anger and depression hit me really hard. I've been 40 years without cancer in my body, but I'll never truly be cancer free.
You‚Äôre an inspiration! Sending you all the good and healing vibes! If you look back, you‚Äôll see that the universe has been supporting you all along. I don't know if you want to know this but HER2 type breast cancer can be triggered amongst vegan/vegetarians because of phyto estrogens. If you have to consume a lot of protein i often told patients its safer to avoid soy based proteins, even certain lentils, vegan substitutes etc and just be a pescetarian. Wild caught fish or just eggs are a safer option. Some women are sensitive to phytoestrogen more so then others. I avoided soy products to be safer. Again I'm not giving medical advice. Its just something I thought I'd share.

TL;DR version:  One thing about your specific cancer you said was it was related to estrogen and a lightbulb went off for me that soy mimics estrogen in the body. I was once vegan after I got diagnosed with my Crohn's and had terrible acne and periods and flare ups in my GI tract and couldn't figure out where I was messing up. My nutritionist told me to avoid soy at all costs. I know it's often a staple in veganism, but I didn't know it was so harmful to woman. I guess because it's pretty much plant estrogen, a double dose.   I wanted to pass this along because it changed my health game just cutting this out. It's sneaky though, they use it as a filler in so many foods. You're so health conscious I know you guys probably see how many forms soy can take in food.   Longer version: My family and I have been watching your channel over a year now and so much of what you've been through hits close to home. My mom had breast cancer and my sister committed suicide both in a span of two years, and though it's not exactly the same thing you guys are going through it has parallels and is extremely traumatic.   After my sister's suicide I was diagnosed with Crohn's Disease and I can't help feel like the stress of it some how played a part in my health. The day of her funeral I couldn't stop throwing up.   I saw you were looking for answers as I was too ten years ago, literally searching out hard to find books and not really knowing what I was needing.   We live near Dallas (Texas) so luckily I found a naturopath/nutritionist/applied kinesiologist/chiropractor who gave me the hard truths I needed to face about environment and disease. She told me "Genetics loads the gun and environment pulls the trigger." I was once vegan after I got diagnosed with my Crohn's and had terrible acne and periods and flare ups in my GI tract and couldn't figure out where I was messing up. My nutritionist told me to avoid soy at all costs. I know it's often a staple in veganism, but I didn't know it was so harmful to woman. It's sneaky though, they use it as a filler in so many foods. You're so health conscious I know you guys probably see how many forms soy can take in food. Bec, I had the same diagnosis in 2018 and I remember the first day of the Red Devil very well.  I had heard that cannabis oil was really helpful before chemo - to help you relax, etc.  I must have taken too much because I was basically off my face and laughing for much of the time ‚Ä¶ it certainly took my mind off anxious thoughts!  I did use the oil each time but lowered the dose - it did seem to work for me! Like you, I found the nurses and the other people having treatment amazing.  In Western Australia, where I am, brilliant free services are available for people going through treatment, which I found so, so helpful.  For example, every time I had chemo I was able to have a foot massage - the red devil had no chance in the face of a brilliant masseuse! - and a couple of times a month I also had reiki which, for me, was incredibly powerful and healing.  Something about the loving hands of a generous stranger sending out healing pulses just made me feel so zen - accepting and focused and positive.  I wonder if that is something that might be available for you - I think you might get a lot from it, too.  Anyway, I hate to think of you guys going through this. It certainly is is a life changing experience but, for what it‚Äôs worth, you learn a lot of stuff about yourself and others that will enrich your experience of the world - as hard as it is at times.  Lots of love to you - I think you are generous and amazing people!

Check out Valter Longo longevity book. He did a study on cancer patients fasting before chemo.   ‚ÄúThe human part of the study was much more limited: a group of cancer patients fasted for 1, 2, or 3 days prior to chemotherapy. The idea is that fasting might reduce the harmful side effects of chemotherapy, particularly the immunosuppression caused by some chemotherapeutic drugs. These results are very preliminary: the patients are participating in a phase I clinical trial, which is designed to assess safety, not effectiveness. Nonetheless, the results indicate that a 3-day fast (but not a 1-day fast) was beneficial for these patients.‚Äù

Your story breaks my heart. Praying for your life.  I wonder if you have heard of people all over the world healing from cancer by eliminating carbohydrates and sugars?  Those feed cancer cells.  We have actually several people in my family with cancer and some no longer with us here because of it.  So please consider the possibly unthinkable...stop eating sugar and carbs and eat animal based only.  My daughter is 16 and keeps her severe eczema in check and clear as long as she strictly eats beef and pink salt and stevia with Sparkling water. Plants have a lot of estrogen hormone.  I had to cut them out because of the hormone mess it made me along with body rashes that lasted months.  I eat meat and a little super high dark chocolate.  It's helping with my myelitis.  Please please please do this!!! YouTube the carnivore diet and healing cancer.  Blessings.
Please take this advice.  My dad went through chemo in 2017 and would not/could not eat....he was so sick.  He was drinking like 1 - Ensure a day.  So I googled a calorie calculator.  How many calories a day to maintain his current weight (he had already lost a lot of weight).  So the calculator gave me "X" calories a day.  We purchased the highest calorie Ensure we could buy and he needed 6 a day - and any extra was a bonus.  He drank Ensure for 8 months I think.  BUT he maintained his weight from when he started this Ensure regimen.  When he could eat....of course.....that was helpful, but continued the 6 Ensure a day until He actually started to gain weight.  You have to get your calories in......one way or another.....even if you just drink them.  God Bless.  Praying for you gal & Eamon (and your family).  Big Love.

Hang on and stay as positive you can. But you don't HAVE to be positive everyday or for anyone else.  I was diagnosed with an aggressive leukemia (AML with a mutation) on July 1. Had a bone marrow transplant in Oct. I went into remission and then unexpectedly relapsed after doing everything "right."   On to round two: stronger IV chemo x 5 days, and will get another infusion of blood cells from my donor this week! I'm lucky to have a fantastic team that I trust. Cancer is not fun, but we can learn life lessons. I learned how loved I am, and how generous and loving people really are. Our partners are going through so much too: Uncertainty, fear, extreme love, and caring. We're on a hard road, but for me right now, there's no option but to keep going forward. Just remember to be grateful to wake up every morning, and keep breathing in and out! Everyone's story is unique. Happy you're sharing yours. Take good care of yourself! ‚ù§Ô∏è P.S. Try not to think about doing this for 5 months. Just take one day at a time. It changes your mindset and makes things more manageable.

I am a breast cancer survivor.  I had the reconstruction done at same time as the breasr removal. I di alot of research prior to surgery but it did not prepare me for what I woke up to. Talk with women who can share their experiences but I feel if it's 10 yrs out or more they may not remember what the initial experience was like. The end results is a belly lift, which you being tiny like me I didn't need. The recovery is different and not like a mom who had "c" section.  The rules of trying to straighten up to walk is a big NO. YOU WILL DO DAMAGE. My sister in law has had double mastectomy stag 4 and did not have reconstruction.  Her daughter due to caring the cancer Gen had her breaststroke removed and stretchers put in. It was a journey but she is happy she chose this path. I want to say we all question what we did wrong.  They once blamed under wire bras. It seems to be something that is dormant in all of us. What triggers it?? For me I believe stress anxiety played a big role.

Chemo survival tips from a survivor: 1. Get some plastic water bottles and freeze them.  Hold them during treatment to help reduce neuropathy. 2. Start oil pulling everyday. It helps prevent mouth ulcers 3. Ginger, ginger, ginger 4. Take the meds to keep the nausea away.  5. Edibles if you can 6. Therapy is the best 7.  Stay hydrated and eat when you‚Äôre hungry. 8. Potatoes are amazing when you are not hungry but you need to eat  9. Be kind to yourself and go outside.  10. This too will pass. Stay strong!   11. Don‚Äôt worry about the wig. Learn how to draw on Your eyebrows and get some great hats!

My very humble and very heartfelt suggestion...in your search is to think outside the box and not dismiss anything that might not be at the forefront or even advised by the professionals. If sugar is the primary fuel for cancer, an organic diet won't help you if it's sugar based. Consider going Keto and starving the cancer. Grains are sugar with the water sucked out, concentrated forms of regular sugar, according to Mark's Daily Apple, so the burritos need to go. Most people cannot image giving up wheat flour which is damaging to most immune systems, and it's not easy by any means but there are plenty of You Tube videos about making bread substitutes available on You Tube. I like Keto Buns. You should check on You Tube for Ted Talks about starving cancer and about how cancers need to make new blood vessels in order to grow, angiogenesis. The best thing any of us can do for our health is to pamper our immune systems. Our immune systems are designed to fight cancers, barring genetic abnormalities, so leanr about your immune system! Your thyroid requires selenium (brazil nuts) and iodine (ocean foods) because every fifteen minutes, if everything is working properly, all the blood in your body passes through your thyroid where it gets a tiny zap, this zap breaks down the outer shell of foreign invaders. Over time the foreign invaders will no longer be able to function, similar to how if you damaged the spike protein on the Corona virus it could not attach itself to your healthy cell. Your digestive system, from mouth to anus, is part of your immune system. We all know about probiotics, which are the gut bacteria required for good health, and maybe we don't know as much about prebiotics, the food the probiotics require, insoluble fiber. This means if you go Keto you MUST get your ten percent of carbohydrates from actual green vegetables, not white carbs like rice and potatoes and not from a green POWDER unless the bottle says HIGH FIBER. You need that fiber! Once of the best things anyone can do for their digestive system and immune health is to give up wheat floor. The wheat gluten can cross the gut barriers and get into your blood stream. where your immune system will go after it because it does not belong there. In the process organs like your thyroid gland can get damaged, those are autoimmune diseases. You want your immune system killng cancer, not chasing wheat gluten around! Your vitamin D3 level needs to be optimized, vitamin D prevents cancer in three ways, according to one of Dr Oz's original television shows. One of those ways is similar to how the thyroid damages cancer cells, it weakens the hard outer shell of cancer cells so that they can no longer perform their desired functions. Check You Tube for videos that Dr Mercola has posted about getting your vitamin D naturally, but, I recently read an article that said two thousand IU of vitamin D3 a day for five years showed no adverse effects. It's a super cheap supplement that also helps to improve your mood. Aiming for eight hours of sleep is also important, I once read that our bodies do more work when we are asleep than when we are awake, repairing the damage of the day. I have seen some cancer patients on You Tube who seem ashamed that they spend a lot of time sleeping, don't feel that way! It's part of the healing process. Lastly I recommend unrefined coconut oil as a skin lotion and a mouth wash. As a mouth wash you need to keep it in your mouth for twenty minutes after every meal, or after anything goes into your mouth, which is the number one entry point for foreign invaders. Unrefined coconut oil It is supposed to be antiviral and antibacterial, the chemo kills your immune system lining your mouth and the germs move in and start making babies. The growing babies cause the pain, the coconut oil will help prevent dryness and wash out those germ babies. I would also recommend any of Suzanne Somer's books about health. She got a breast cancer diagnosis and be cause she was a celebrity she managed to interview several experts on the subject. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzanne_Somers

Thanks for such a beautiful video. The love that shines through the two of you is going to get you to the finish line. All of my memories of chemo came to my mind as I watched you. If there is any time to dislike Covid19 it‚Äôs now when you can‚Äôt have Eamon with you. I had friends drive me to all of my treatments except the first and the last. Having a friend with me helped to keep my mind positive. The Cancer centre in London was always filled with older patients. I got my strength from their strength. Each treatment day I was also blessed with emails from my cousin who is a retired minister. She would send a picture of a flower or just something beautiful yet simple. Her messages also kept me positive. I would also have dinners brought to the house from neighbours or from our hockey families. This was so thoughtful since my husband was working (self employed contractor). Also while I was getting my Liquid Sunshine, my youngest was in grade 12, trying to maintain the grades and studying and get applications out for Uni and plan for prom. She was so strong for me and I was strong and positive for her. I think she realized that she wanted to study Nursing because of me. excess estrogen from a copper imbalance is what is causing these types of cancers... there's a great supplement called calcium d-glucarate that helps pull out the excess estrogen naturally. you could add it into your routine.... bc its not that you aren't a healthy eating, healthy lifestyle person but its a copper imbalance that most of us women have. Its not something regular doctors know anything about bc the copper imbalance is hidden deep in the tissues. its the way the body protects itself by hiding it. It was only the first pee that came out red for me. I believe that‚Äôs it.  Just use the meds given to help with the side effects. Hindsight I wish I did. I always try to tough things out and not take drugs but there is a middle ground. I had a nulasta injection the  day after each chemo and I think it was that that, that put me in the most pain, at least that‚Äôs what i thought the pain was from since one side effect was bone pain. I wish I didn‚Äôt try to tough it out like I did.  I was Dx at age 44.  I was healthy and very active and now  still healthy at 60 and very active compared to most 60 year olds. You‚Äôll be amazed how resilient most of us humans are and how you will be. I haven‚Äôt been through what you are going through, but I have struggled with chronic illness for the past decade - two things that help me a ton is the Spoon Theory and having a ‚Äúday‚Äù bed. The spoon theory is a way of understanding your emotional and physical energy with illness, and just moving to a different place for the day and keeping it separate from where I sleep at night (even if I sleep all day, it‚Äôs in the day bed) helps my sleep quality and mindset. ‚ù§Ô∏è
Bec, I can hear you lean into the *_yes I can_* mantra.  *YES* you most certainly can.  Bec you hit on something that will be so important in tending to yourself during this --- that cycle -- the times when you are well vs sick, when you are strong vs weak, tired vs energetic.  Mastering that cycle through your treatments is what will you give you a much needed sense of control.  It will lessen disappointment that can come with planning something at the wrong time only to have bow out.  Also, I have suggested to people I have worked with that they try to revisualize what is happening when they are feeling really bad after a treatment.  Chemo is like a terrible best friend, right?  It is absolutely going to purge your body of these disruptive, unwelcomed cells --- and it will pound on some good cells in the process --- of course you want it to pound like mad!  But it's crazy to be saying _please keep doing this wonderful thing...that makes me feel _*_so_*_ not wonderful_ .   But Bec, picture it doing its work.  Creating this type of visualization helped them (some of the women I worked with) to start feeling like -- when they were feeling their worst, was when the chemo was working the hardest.  These subtle shifts in perspective, aided by strong visualization work, can be remarkably effective.  ...continuing to send so much healing energy your way.

Here's the thing about cancer.... It doesn't care if you're healthy or not. If you eat only organic, or not. It's so easy to say, "science will fix this" or "science won't fix this". In the world, as we know it, science is the best resource we can ever rely on. Keep pushing. Keep fighting. Because in the end, we can only do our best. Tomorrow is never guaranteed. üíô

Cancer is not bad luck it's usually hereditary. I had cervical cancer when I was in my 30's. I had radiation treatment. I wished I had done my own research on natural healing rather then taking radiation. I have had side affects from the radiation treatments that have changed my bladder since then. There is no way in hell I would ever put chemo poisons in my body. The damage chemo does to your good blood cells is not worth the risk in my personal opinion. Cancer runs in all the women on my mothers side of my family. They all went through chemo treatments only for a new type of cancer to develop months later. They all eventually died from cancer. My mom and my 3 aunts. I am not a Debbie downer just a realist who has been there. I am a cancer survivor of 30 years now. I am 66 years old. I take care of my body and eat organic, vegan foods. I am not on any medications. I believe in natural healing and the power of prayer. I will be praying for you that God will give you strength and your body will be able to over come the poisons that chemo leaves inside of you.

Some of the best advice I received from my breast surgeon when I expressed how afraid I was about being sick was you'll go through your 1st round of chemo you'll see what it's like and then that's what you can expect so you can prepare.
