I have prayed for you, Bec. I'm so sorry you're going through this ordeal. I admire your positivity. I believe trusting Eamon's distrust of the medical industry is HIGHLY advisable. People get cured of cancer, not because of their toxic treatment (many die from it), but in spite of it. Stats show that most die within 5 years because the cancer returns elsewhere in their bodies eventually. Chemo and radiation actually cause cancer and destroy your immune system.  It's no wonder you're confused as to why you got cancer in the first place after such a healthy lifestyle. One thing to consider if you've had the Covid shot: Doctors are reporting dramatic increases in cancer cases in vaccinated patients. Rates of other illnesses in the vaxed have also soared, esp. clotting issues.  It's so good you're eating healthy, but at this time ramping up your diet to radical juicing and eating 80-85% raw is paramount. (Cooking food kills the enzymes your body so desperately needs.) Please consider doing a Gerson-type diet which has cured many from cancer as well as other illnesses. I urge you to check out Dr. Lorraine Day's webpage and diet.  I wish you well from my heart and will keeping praying for God to continue to give you much strength and courage through this challenging time! It saved a lot and I mean a LOT of lives.  Survival rates have gone up year-by-year!    This chemicals and the immunotherapy (herceptin and other monoclonal antibodies) will destroy the bad stuff (and true also some of the good stuff).  And if you get radiotherapy (some doctors do and other do not.. not all breast cancers are the same) that will be part of the battle.  Rest a lot! And drink a lot (as your body has to excrete the garbage breakdown products from the treatment)  !  Eat proteins as after breaking down your body also needs to build.. proteins matter!  Proteins is the stuff your muscles and organs are made of.  And you need carbohydrates!  Because this period your body is doing double duty and needs the energy. Bec first off there are this like hard candy that will help with sickness while doing liquid sunshine. It is mainly for women who are pregnant but can also be used for when people are going for liquid sunshine to help deal with the sickness. The brand name of the one that I know is called Preggie Pop drops, if there is any maternity stores or you can order them online. You might be able to find others, I just know of these as my dad and grandfather used them when they were dealing with their liquid sunshine and it help them. When I was expecting my son they help with my all day sickness. It might be something to look into to help.

I‚Äôve been through ‚Äúliquid sunshine‚Äù for triple negative breast cancer in 2015 and 2018. I lost my hair the first time but used a cooling cap on the second one and mostly kept my hair. I recommend it if you can find a way to access it. If you take some treatments that risks neuropathy (numbness from damaged nerves in hands and feet) I really recommend to ice your hands and feet during administration as this reduces blood flow just to those areas that don‚Äôt need treatments anyway which reduces exposure to the chemicals. It avoids pain and a weird numbness in your feet that can sometimes be permanent (I mostly avoided long term problems but had to reduce my treatment dose part way through) and in your hands it avoids numbness and clumsiness. I kept dropping my knives and forks after my first treatments. My coordination hasn‚Äôt come back 100% but I went from really good beforehand to average now. Second time around in 2018 I iced them and avoided the problems. I just used ice packs but you can get specialised cooler gloves that I know others have used in another hospital that I didn‚Äôt go to.  I had the ‚Äúred devil‚Äù first time with another drug at the same time. I don‚Äôt think that causes neuropathy but other drugs that come later probably will. Well done with the exercise. As hard as that might be I discovered it‚Äôs one of the most important things you can do for yourself away from the doctors for long term recovery.   Good luck with everything. You‚Äôre doing really well. You have so much support. It‚Äôs great to see.

I commented on your first cancer video, and I will try to leave a little message on each week's video, in case it helps you to know that I can relate to many parts of your experience. ‚ù§  I mentioned that I have been largely bedridden and housebound for the past 2 years with ME/CFS.   There are some days where I feel less weak / fatigued and I can stand up and cook a meal and I have to agree with you... it's one if the BEST feelings to be able to do simple human things that make me feel productive and not so useless! I have been having an exceptionally good week, and have been able to do lots of things that bring me joy, like getting organized for gardening (I just planted my first round of winter seeds!), working on an acrylic painting, getting my own groceries (a VERY rare occurrence), and cooking lots of fresh food!  I can also relate to that lingering thought of this will only be short lived, and soon I will find myself back in bed, riddled with pain, unable to open my blinds (due to severe light sensitivity during a flare), sleeping and resting, and being cared for by my loved ones. üíô  It takes so much mental and physical strength and perseverance to go through these types of experiences, so just know that I see that and recognize that, and applaud you for getting through each day with so much gentle compassion for wherever you are in your journey.

Bec, or Eamon. There's something you need to be aware of when having your surgery. That's the chance of developing Lymphedema afterwards. Most likely in one or both of your arms. It causes swelling and a lot of other stuff you'd rather not know about right now. You should talk to your doctors about this now so if it should happen you can get on top of it fast so that it won't have as big an effect on your lifestyle or health. The problem is most doctors don't know anything about Lymphedema. Surgeons are more likely to know about it. I wasn't so lucky and years went by with me asking doctors about what was happening to my legs and getting no answers. When I finally found a vascular surgeon he took one look and sent me to the local lymphedema clinic for treatment but by that time I was already at stage 3 (worst stage for lymphedema) and my life and health are miserable dealing with it for hours a day. Every day, non-stop. So, I hope you'll take heed and educate yourself, keep an eye open for any signs and get therapy asap. IF it happens and IF you catch it early you will thank yourself for forever.
so so proud of you both..you'redoing great...keep holding on to the little things and releasing the yukkies
Oh my gosh, you take me back. I used to go to chemo sessions with my second husband after his diagnosis of brain cancer and after his surgery. I was there for the surgical recovery, but he thought I was a fat man with a cigar and because he couldn't smoke, I pissed him off. And I went for the radiation but you can't go in because, duh, it's radiation. But I loved all the markings on his now-bald head where the radiologist would color differently and I would imagine that had to do with angle, level, etc. We agreed they'd make some vicious tattoos. And then chemo was last, so we'd play cards while he was in the hospital getting his infusion. I would ask the nurse, "When is he getting the stuff that makes him goofy? I never win unless he's goofy." She thought that was hysterical because, I guess, it's a pretty depressing situation for most people but we were just this amazing team of young people, blissfully unaware and determined to just carry on. We did, he was cured, but he'd become quite disturbed by the ordeal so please do take good care of your mental health. He is gone now, and not from cancer, and the tears on my cheek should tell you that I am writing you from my heart. I want you to live, but I want you to be happy more than anything. Please don't just live your life, love your life. And if you don't one day, you can change it overnight. I've done it several times and as a Native American Elder, I will say, it's not easy, but it's totally worth it.
Bec, you are doing everything right.  One further tip from my mother, who had a lifelong heart issue and who faced three open-heart surgeries, is this.  When I asked her what she does to get through it, she said she envisions the time after, and makes plans, ie, this time next week I will be back in my own bed, this time next month I will be healing on the couch watching movies, this time next year I will be going on a trip.  She made plans for the immediate, medium, and far future and kept those plans in the forefront of her mind.  For whatever reason that my mother was faced with this challenge in life, it made her an incredibly empathetic and wise human that spread gentle understanding and kindness all around her.  It elevated her to a higher consciousness.  For me, I learned that pain and trauma is to be embraced for what it can teach us.  Easy to say, I know, and harder to do.  I think you are doing it.  Love and light to you, Warrior Woman!

Hi, I‚Äôm a new friend to your channel. I want to let you know first of all your not alone in this fight, so many others including myself are fighting alongside of you. Im going to tell you about my start of my breast cancer journey. I was diagnosed with stage 2 triple negative breast cancer back Nov.5, 2020,..that will always be a day I will never forget. That day was a whirlwind and I think I was pretty much in shock because I let out a little laugh when the dr told me my biopsy results showed breast cancer and it was more than likely stage 3. It took a little bit for that information to sink in then it hit me hard. That day my life changed completely but even though it was a sad scary day I still tried to see the good into being diagnosed with breast cancer. This year has been a hard fight and I couldn‚Äôt imagine having to do this fight alone. From Dec 2020 to June 2021 I went through 14 hard rounds of the strongest chemo out there in hopes to kill out the cancer. My lump was 5cm which is about the size of a golf ball but they were hopeful the 3 different types of chemos I had to take would kill out the cancer and shrink the lump and thankfully it did shrink the lump down very small compared to what it was. The first two chemo I took was together in one setting and was Doxorubicin and Cyclophosphamide and I did 4 rounds of it. One had the nickname the red devil and met me tell ya it was! That chemo was the one that made me lose my pretty hair in just 14days after starting it.! Next was the Paclitaxel and it ended up making me lose the rest of my lashes and brows, it also caused me some mild joint pain and mild neuropathy issues but thankfully those issues are fading away thank the good lord y hair and all of that are now slowly but surely growing.  Anyway my cancer lump went from 5cm down to 1cm. During that time I was on chemo I lost all my pretty hair, and then the lashes and eyebrows and was so sick with severe nausea and weakness and all of that really took a toll on me mentally and physically. After I finished chemo in June they did a repeat scan of my whole body inside and out and there were no signs of cancer to be seen but that didn‚Äôt mean cancer wasn‚Äôt hiding in there somewhere so I‚Äôm now taking chemo pills for a few months as a precautionary things because the lump they removed from my breasts did test positive still for a small percentage of cancer but not as bad as it was so the chemo pills will help get anything that is hiding. So as for now I am in early remission and I hope I can say I am completely cancer free someday. Early august I had to do my first surgery for a double mastectomy then a week later I had to do a second surgery to have breast expanders put in to start the breast reconstruction process that I am truly grateful for getting to have the opportunity to do. Many women don‚Äôt get that chance because of where they lump/lumps are located and thankfully mine was located at the base of my right breast and I was able to do the skin sparing/nipple saving breast reconstruction. I will be doing hopefully my third and hopefully my last surgery coming up soon that is called a exchange surgery where they will exchange the expanders that has helped stretch the breast skin and replacing them with breast implants. I have been documenting the past 12months showing the good bad and the ugly sides of dealing with breast cancer and will be putting all those videos and photos into one cancer journey video and I hope soon to share it on my channel in hopes to help someone else with my experiences I had to go through during my breast cancer journey. Sending all my love and prayers your way and know you got this fight. Never lose hope and fight hard! God will help guide you through this journey. Sorry for the long comment but I felt in my heart to tell you or anyone else dealing with this awful disease that you have a forever friend here with me and you will not fight alone! Sending much love and prayers from southeast Kentucky üíôüíó

When I was going through 10 months of recovery from multiple knee surgeries in a straight leg brace, I would say to myself "it is what it is". Sounds too simple to be worth anything, but it did help having that mind set and having a way to express it, even if it was just to myself. Then when it came time to recover from having a brace on my leg for so long, which took, believe it or not, 2.5 years, to get rid of any sign of a limp and be able to walk without pain. I had to go through sometimes a lot of pain to get full range of motion again. I had to say to myself "I just want my life back" to push myself hard. My advise to you, is get outside as much as you can. You live in a beautiful place. Treasure nature and people that support you. It helps soooo much. I had to do my bit alone and It is sad to say (after I figured out a way to drive) that for me there were times when just parking in the Target parking lot just watching people was the event of my day. How sad is that. Eventually I could I would spend time next to the water where I would kayak a lot. That motived me to get that knee bent enough to figure out a way to get into a kayak. Anyway, enough of me. You will get through it and come out a stronger person after it all. It will go faster than you think. Keep that in mind. In the mean time I'll keep you in my prays and thoughts. Take care and stay positive. Lean on Eamon. He obviously loves you and is there to lean on, not to mention he can cook. Bonus!

I went and had genetic testing done about 2 years ago. I have Lynch Syndrome,  I got it from my dad's maternal side. I go every year now for cancer screenings like colonoscopy and endoscopy. My dad had colon cancer back in 2013 and had to do chemo and radiation therapy he also has his right side of the colon removed. In 2020 he had to have surgery again on his duodenum as there was a pre-cancerous lesion. My dad was upset when he found out I had Lynch Syndrome but like I said to him I am not mad as actually I am happy to know I have it and I can be proactive with my cancer screenings.
The first chemo is the worst 1 but it does get a little Easier I had stage 3 breast cancer with some off my lymph‚Äôs affected to I had a mastectomy I chose not to have reconstruct but I‚Äôm jst over 5 years cancer free and chemo is ruff I wish you all the luck in the world I‚Äôm shour you will do jst great and come out the other side great‚Ä¶xxxxx

My father in law had a really positive mental and emotional attitude about getting Chemo. He would say to himself ‚ÄúGod is in the chemo as he watched it enter his body‚Äù.   Over ten years later Chemo has destroyed his kidneys and heart and now he has prostate cancer. His drs flat out said his issues are a direct result of the Chemo. He says getting chemo is like trying to get rid of weeds by cutting them at the surface leaving behind the roots.   A dr I work for says ‚ÄúChemo is the gift that keeps on giving‚Äù. His wife went thru Chemo treatment over 10 years ago for colon cancer and now has vaginal cancer as a direct result of the chemotherapy. Her hip is destroyed by the chemo and she needs a hip replacement at 55yrs old.   Chemo comes with a lifetime of damaging health repercussions. Please watch The Truth about Cancer docu-series by Ty Bollinger. There are other options.

Hi Bec, I already had my chemo for two cycles due to my ovarian cancer. The first one was last 2018 in the Philippines and the second one was here in Oregon, USA last 2020. Keep up the great work here, I am pulling for you. A moment that I really appreciated from this video was the connection you made between your healthy lifestyle and your cancer diagnosis. I have been following your channel for some time, and see first hand how health and wellness is a huge part of your way of being. Cancer is one of those diseases that can present in even the MOST healthy people. It sometimes just boils down to probability, and one cannot ruminate about what they could have done to try and prevent the onset of the disease. Your healthy lifestyle will carry you through this episode in your life, your strength and the medical technology will see you through to a future where this is just a memory. Hey lady, and her gentleman, glad to see you really working as a team. What a precious gift. I wanted to share that my mom went through this journey. And she lost her hair. I always saw her with a scarf or hat. One day I came and said "Let's go out." So she went and took a shower and put her makeup on. And she had no head covering. I asked "Why with that perfect head are you wearing hats and scarves? You literally look gorgeous without it. Stunning!" So she stopped wearing them. I am breast cancer survivor and all your questions about "What did I do to deserve this?" "Why me?" are ones that I dealt with. Fact is, it just happens.   It's nothing you did or didn't do.   My mom died of stage 4 breast cancer at age 54. She was diagnosed and passed away within 6 months.  So, when I was diagnosed, it was exactly 20 years since she had been diagnosed.  I thought that maybe it was because of her that I ended up with it. But nope.   I had the FULL genetic testing done on me. My grandma had been diagnosed with uterine cancer and survived. Breast and uterine cancer are related.   But my genetic testing came back that it was just basically a fluke that I had been diagnosed with breast cancer.   You've got this Bec! You've got this! It's like a grieving process. You're allowed to feel all the emotions. You'll have good days and days that you will want to punch a wall out of aggravation and frustration.   You have an entire community rallying behind you. And just think, these are people that you have never met! That says an awful lot.   With love and healing thoughts from Pennsylvania.

Ramon and Bec.  -Best wishes -  My journey with breast cancer was back in 2012.  The doctors took very good care of me and still are.  Acceptance of your treatment is very helpful to your mental state.  I continue to be on tamoxifen for a period of ten years will come off next year.   Please remember there are some great nausea medications.  I used the Sancuso patch, it was left on for 4 days and I never was nausea.  The expense is worth it when you have so many other symptoms to deal with.  Keep your chin up you and your care givers are most important during this time.

Bec, I‚Äôve gone through three years of chemo for leukemia. Two relapses... and a CAR-T cell transplant in October that has me remission again and should be lasting without any more chemo ever again...   The chemo is bad and draining... but as long you can rest and do the things before treatment and after it‚Äôs also not as bad as it seems...  I always recommend drinking lots of water, the day before and eating light the day before and day of... eat as something light as soon you finish treatment before falling asleep. Broccoli cheddar soup got me through so many days when I couldn‚Äôt eat much. And organic popsicles like Outshine are a great way to stir your appetite and settle your stomach after treatments. I also recommend watching cooking and food YouTube channels when you feel too sick to eat to stir your appetite... pickles and olives are great healthy snacks to get rid of the icky taste in your mouth. And I recommend protein20 flavored waters... most of them like Watermelon Strawberry are really natural and delicious and help replenish electrolytes when you throw up.   ensures are lifesavers because it gives you the nutrition and protein you need to replace some meals when it‚Äôs hard to eat... the only downside is the sugar... but it‚Äôs the only sugar I kept in my diet other than natural sugars from fruits. But the Vanilla Plus Ensures are really easy to get down and can hold you over when you don‚Äôt have energy to make a meal or desire to sit up and chew anything but need something in your art that will satiate your appetite til the nausea passes.   I also highly recommend Aloha protein shakes and Chocolate brownie bars... natural juices and smoothies are good when you can get them in but I found it hard many days. It‚Äôs important to accept you just won‚Äôt be able to eat as balanced and healthy as you like but find the comfort foods and things that give you enough nutrition and protein to get by.   Also, please look up Dr William Li and his book ‚ÄúEat To Beat Disease‚Äù he does a lot of podcasts and lives on his Instagram as well... very insightful research and information he‚Äôs collected...  Most of all, I know your positive and approaching this with a good mindset already, you have more direct support than I‚Äôve had, but just keep your mind distracted when your sick with Comedies and Rom Coms and things that make you feel happy and thoughts in a lite place. Curate and cut out everything else during this time. Laughter is truly the best medicine, make it point to find something that will make you laugh everyday.   Distraction is the best tool when you feel sick. Music can be heeling, but again, I recommend making a playlist of uplifting  happy music and things like the Rocky Theme... anything too melancholy or nostalgic is not the best I find. Meditation music  and instrumental soft sounds and waves and stuff are the best I found.  I also recommend Sailing La Vagebonde to escape when in the hospital.  You guys, and them and kinging it all got me through so many long hospital days and stays getting treatment the last three years and allowed my mind to escape the hospital chair and travel vicariously.  Thank you so much for all the content and positive energy I‚Äôve received from you on my journey.  You got this. We got this.  And rest rest rest like you said.  Rest, laugh, distract, hydrate, eat well, repeat. That‚Äôs all you need to focus on.  And look into the cold therapy and Wim Hof, though I think you‚Äôre already familiar with it in Canada. But it does more for your energy then anything. Just keep your mind meditative and and calm and focused on breathing when you‚Äôre in the cold and stay in it til it feels comfortable. The longer you stay in it calmly and feel comfortable and at peace with it, focused on your breathing the better you‚Äôll feel when you get out of it.   So much love and positive vibes sent your way.   Namaste.

I had stage 2 colon cancer.. I did 6 months of chemo.. my friend used to call it LIQUID GOLD.. I was on the same schedule as you.. the first week is bad and then the second week is to build your strength back up.. before chemo.. Some stupid jokes for ya to make ya smile.  An Englishman, Frenchman, Spaniard, and German are all trying to watch a street performer juggle knives. Unfortunately, it's such a busy day in the city, there are too many other people around to see clearly. Luckily, the juggler notices their plight and decides to climb onto a higher platform so the four men can see. As he balances a knife on his nose, he asks, "Can you see me now?" The four men reply one after the other, "Yes!" "Oui!" "Si!" "Ja!" Sherlock Holmes and Watson are on a camping trip. After a good session of singing Wonderwall around the campfire, they retire to their sleeping bags. Several hours later, Sherlock wakes up and nudges Watson awake. Watson groggily asks, "What?" "Watson, look up at the sky and tell me what you see." Watson thinks about this for a minute, wiping his eyes. "I see millions of stars," Watson answers. "What does that tell you?" asks Sherlock. "Well, astronomically, it tells me there are millions of galaxies. Astrologically, I can see that Saturn is in Virgo. Theologically, I see that God is all-powerful and we are insignificant. What does it tell you, Holmes?" Sherlock remains silent for a few seconds. "It tells me that someone has stolen our tent."  A frog decides to visit a fortune teller to find out if he'll ever find his princess. The fortune teller reads his palm and after a few brief moments of contemplation, begins her reading. "I have good news and I have bad news. Which would you like to hear first?" The frog, anxious for the possibility of true love, chooses the good news first. "You are going to meet the most beautiful girl," the fortune teller says. "She's going to be very interested in you and will know everything there is to know about you. You'll open up to her and give her your heart." Pleased, the frog then cautiously asks for the so-called bad news. To this, the fortune teller replies, "You'll meet her in a Biology class."  One of the oddities of Wall Street is that it is the dealer and not the customer who is called broker.¬†  Two hunters are out in the woods when one of them collapses. He doesn't seem to be breathing and his eyes are glazed. The other guy whips out his phone and calls the emergency services. He gasps, "My friend is dead! What can I do?". The operator says "Calm down. I can help. First, let's make sure he's dead." There is a silence, then a shot is heard. Back on the phone, the guys says "OK, now what?"
Sending SO much LOVE ‚ô•Ô∏è, STRENGTH ü¶æüèãÔ∏è, and SUPPORT ü•∞üéâ to you both during this time! You WILL GET THROUGH IT. Genetics can cause cells to be more likely to react to chemicals put on and in the body. ORGANIC (chemical free farming etc.) food, lotions, cleaning supplies etc worked for me!! 'All-natural' does not mean chemical free. Infact I have my biology course links to give you more info: "Chemicals and your health" https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/emes/public/docs/Chemicals,%20Cancer,%20and%20You%20FS.pdf.  In healthy cells, they send good chemical signals to different parts to tell the cell what to do such as the mitochondria to produce energy, and also when it's ready to split into 2 cells. Other bad chemicals contacting your skin, lungs, and digestive system can enter your digestive system and those bad chemicals can travel through the body and give the wrong signals to your cells. If the bad chemicals tell your cells to grow too fast and split, grow and split. Groups of too many cells are called tumors, which you shared about in your videos. I recommend researching credible, factual sites on living an Organic lifestyle -if- you aren't already. I feel you, Bec, as when I started chemo it was SO hard! I'm so glad you have Bec there, I was alone.I did chemo and organic lifestyle. Then, I'm not saying anyone should do this, but I quickly stopped chemo (it wasn't for me) and went on an all organic lifestyle, it was amazing!  I know you will make the best decisions for you! You will fight, you will be strong, and you will overcome this!! Be strong (both of you!!) You've got this!!!

It‚Äôs a very hard time, my son was diagnosed with lymphoma two years ago, went thru chemo, radiation surgery and lots of visits to ICU. Had to go through so many weeks of treatment, after the cancer came back he had a stem cell transplant.. now in remission for 6 months. Prayers to you both.
Best thing you can do for your body is drink as much water as you can stand, avoid soy, and load up on high protien foods which I know is tough..maybe protein drinks?.  Also...other than soy, eat what you want....you will find out pretty quickly that your favorite foods wont be your favorites for long...chemo does that to you. Also get a port...makes getting chemo and other meds so much easier..

Careful with those goji berries...and foods high in antioxidants in general.  The way chemotherapy (in your particular cocktail)  works is that the medications generate free radicals that are meant to attack the cancer cells.  Antioxidants will have an opposing effect on the chemo and get rid of those free radicals and your treatment won't work as well...

Bec, I kept a little note book with positive messages and reminders written by me to me while going through chemo. I would refer back to it on those hard days, and found these messages surprisingly comforting. It helped so much to note what made me feel better in those hard moments during treatment. By the end of chemo I had quite the field guide for navigating challenging days. I am happy to report that was 10 years ago...sending you and Eamon all the very best.

Just remember- the cancer doesn't care about your mood. If you have days, weeks where you feel low, negative, or other, the chemo will do its things regardless. You don't have to be a strong positive warrior all the time. And you are not a bad person or giving cancer the power for having down days. Even grumpy people beat cancer.  I know we think about it as a fight and a war - but that implies that someone is not strong enough if they lose. And that's not fair to them. Be strong, be weak, be positive, and grumpy - be you. All the love ‚ù§Ô∏è

When my mother had colorectal cancer they needed to grow the cancer growing in her lung (she'd metastasised) and they used glucose to grow the cancer to take photos of it inside as it was so small. After that she stopped eating so many carbohydrates, fruits, pastas and potatoes as well as treats ie cake and biscuits as we all couldn't believe how quickly her cancer spot on her lungs grew with just a small amount of glucose. Take good care lovely and all love and healing to you xx

Love the hair cut, super cute. I remember when my friend was going through treatment she said she didn't want to be a cancer survivor, she wanted to be a person who had had cancer. It wasn't all she was. So I determined to do , say and act the same and if she wanted to talk about it I would follow her lead. Just like anything else she had gone through . There were so many funny moments in her journey and we still laugh at them. Find the humour in the most horrible thing and you will prevail. IE: When my friend was telling me about how it felt when her hair started growing back she mentioned she had found one tiny hair sticking out of her head. As the days passed that one hair sort of took on its own life and charger. Because she was an artist I suggested she visualize one strand hair styles. We came up with some seriously  funny hairstyles. But the one she remembers with a smile on her face is when I suggested she protect it in a straw and put little bows on different straws. . Colour coorindinate the bows to her mood. She didn't actually do it but it brought such a smile to her and a giggle when she visualized it. Another funny moment was when she was going through reconstruction  and mentioned all she wanted was her new nipples. As it was xmas I started singing all I want for xmas is my new nipples. We both started laughing hysterically while everyone around us thought we were crazy. We have the same sense of humour so it was funny to us. The point I guess is you will find what works for you. It doesn't have to be what everyone else does. It just has to be what makes it easier and true to who you are. Cancer will always be a part of the journey but it isn't THE journey. It isn't all you are, you are so much more. You have a great partner and there will be days where you will need to be there for him as well. Be you and be happy.
I love you oso very much üê∂
You have no idea how much this vlog series you‚Äôre doing will help others who end up going through the same journey.  It‚Äôs the not knowing, and fearing, what‚Äôs ahead that really gets to you.  I had to go through about 6 months of pausing life to get through a medical thing.  I went online and found peoples‚Äô diaries of their similar journeys, and it helped SO much. It can help with feeling like there‚Äôs a fairly predictable beginning, middle, and END.  Stuff like your toilet picture of the red pee will take away the shock value when someone else sees the same thing.  Everything you can share will help someone else feel more comfortable and confident and patient.  This is an excellent thing you‚Äôre doing.

Ok I pulled over to write a little note. Your reactions were spot on to my own when I was diagnosed with leukemia. I thought I had done something wrong and that‚Äôs why I got it but as my dad says: ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the cards you were dealt!‚Äù And you can handle this. I also had the red devil but my pee was orange but it made me feel awful but it wasn‚Äôt the worst out of all the different chemos I had. I did treatment for 3 years and even became bedridden but I‚Äôm still going! I‚Äôll tell you 2 things that helped me that may help you. 1. It‚Äôs ok to not eat during chemo. I found that fasting during and after was better and recovered faster. 2. Watermelon slushee. Just ice and cut up watermelon. It help sooth my stomach sooo much. Hope this encourages you some! You can do it!! ‚ù§Ô∏è

My husband had cancer in the 80s, at the age of 41. One of the most important things we found out to be important besides being  positive,  was having a lot of laughter in and around you. Laughter is a healing process,  to keep the positivity flowing. Many movies,  joking around with each other (very difficult at times, had to work at it), our children would put on little plays for their father. It's 30 plus years that my husband left us, watching Bec, going through this process,  is very emotional for me.  So,  I going to send positive energy for her.  Part of me would like to start a prayer group with their followers,  where we set a time for each of us, pray for the healing power of the Holy Spirit.  If a prayer time has been set, please let us know.

Get a grip of yourself.  And start doing ice baths. The stress and anxiety is no good, be calm.  Cancer lives from stress and anxiety because the body is not calm but disturbed. Do Wim Hof breathing exercises while grounding or ice baths. You will notice a difference if you do it everyday.  Cancer does not live in extreme cold of extreme heat. Ginger or other root herbal plants will help with the nausea. :) Take care all the best. :)

Hi guys! I heard you say you don't understand what's "filling the bucket." I am currently healing from mold toxicity and before my diagnosis I felt the same way. I ate healthy, I did everything I possibly could to feel well and I was still sick. I am linking an article that explains how some mold toxins cause breast cancer. I have no idea if this is part of your journey - but it is one of those things that western medical doctors never look into. It took me 20 years to get my diagnosis and after doing all the right things I feel like I have a whole new life!! The best test you can do is Real Time Labs. Make sure to take liposomal glutathione before testing because when I took my first test it was completely negative for any toxins. That was because my body wasn't getting them out at all in my urine. When I took the liposomal glutathione and tested again I was highly positive for every toxin. Obviously PLEASE talk to a doctor before doing anything but I just wanted to put it out there that there are other toxins that we don't even think about that could be all around us. An old cabin would be the perfect breeding ground for mold. I wish you all the best on your journey regardless of causation, I deeply believe in your ability to heal and your body's innate wisdom. xoxoxoxo - Miranda

If God brings you to it... he will bring you through it. I know you are searching for answers as to why or how this is happening to you. Years ago, I developed many autoimmune issues and chronic pain disorders. Always wondered why me. In 2014 my daughter was exposed to pesticide poisoning and developed heavy metal toxicity. Which led to chronic pain and illness.. Years of doctors, meds, treatments led her to management and healing. But who best to heal her heart, mind and emotions but me! When you're on a long journey focus on what's coming in the next week or two and enjoy every minute.  What's coming in a month, or two, or three will take care of itself.  That's the biggest lesson I learned when I hiked the Appalachian Trail, I always focused on getting to the goal for the day or the next town I could get supplies.  If I had focused on getting to the end the goal would have seemed impossible from the beginning.  Stay strong you can get through this!

To all, please know that all Cancer journeys are different. We each go through our own ups and downs at different times. We feel different day to day. We can not compare each others side effects as we each get different ones to different degrees or none at all. What keeps us sane and going is the will to see tomorrow.  Bec, your feeling and reacting as you should. I was told to be careful what you eat. If food or beverage start having a metal taste don't eat or drink it. Also, don't eat your favorite foods cause if they get that metal taste your not going to want to eat them anymore. For a sore throat or mouth ask for miracle rince. Its a mouth rinse that helps. Gargling helps too. Ginger is a good tummy aid. Tea was good too. I can remember laughing and than just like that crying. It made no sense to me. It's just the emotions you feel at the time. It's okay to go with what your feeling. And keep journaling it will get better. And I agree with what Eamon said.. it goes by like a windwhirl. Faster than you can breath and absorb it. Just keep going through it. I know 5 months seems like such a long time. Its not.. its the fear of the unknown that makes it seem that way. Always count it down.  1 down 7 to go, 2 down 6 to go. It makes it easier to know what you've accomplished. It's like yes I did it, I can do it and survive. It hives you inner strength. Just feel and do you. Prayers and blessings for you both.

Full love and support.   I know you eat super healthy things, but be mindful that certain foods can interact with medications. Especially in the citrus and supplements. What happens is the enzymes in the fruit (and supplements) will bind with the drugs preventing them from being absorbed as they need to. Grapefruit, pamelo, certain oranges are biggest concerns. Ginkgo may slow blood clotting after surgery.  While normally all these things are super good for you - when other things are interjected into the daily they may not be.  Please cross reference your foods for interactions while you are going through this.   As a cancer survivor - you are not responsible for what is happening. Do what you can to stay stress free, laugh through the hard times, and make all the comfy and cozy things a priority.
Did you take the c-19 vax? One of results is cancer.And no one is in control of their health and body completely, God is.

URGENT: Hey Eamon & Bec... I'm shocked they're not giving you anything to counter the nausea and sick feelings...  I've been seriously injured in an attack on me by 12 assholes who literally beat me almost to death.  Long story short... I had a double spinal surgery a little over a year ago that has crippled me. So, I've had to use crutches and I have an electric wheelchair I have to use to get around...  I'm having to use very strong narcotics to help with my pain control that causes a lot of nausea and sick feelings. They gave me some Ondansetron 4mg disintegrating tablets to counter the nausea and sick feeling. I can promise you that it really works. (Sounds like "On dance a tron")  Ask your Dr's to give you a prescription for Ondansetron 4mg tablets. hey Bec, it's not common but you can get tested for the concentration of BPA, other plastics, and fluorine/chlorine-based synthetic compounds in your breast tissue  I'm 29 and had chronic illness (EDS type 3) for years that disabled my hands and shoulders and I'm finally getting better and working full-time as a programmer again. it got so bad that I developed multiple chemical sensitivity (MCS) & learned there are endocrine disruptors in cookware, building materials (plywood, glue, sealants, paint, etc.), cleaning products, plumbing systems for our water, plastic tupperware, baking sheets, metal water bottle lining, most of the indoor air we breathe, etc.   I used to work at a vegan restaurant about 9 years ago but these days tragically I can't manage to eat any processed foods without pain including beans (even coffee), grains, pseudo-grains, potatoes, fermented foods, etc. It's tough since my diet is pretty much just grass-fed beef/bone broth/tallow & organic broccoli, cauliflower, lettuce, celery, mushrooms, a tiny bit of R2 resistant corn starch for fiber, and whole almonds. Hopefully you don't get sick in the way I am 'cause it's super tough to travel and even hold a job, but I'm finally doing better.  Maybe look into gut microbiome biodiversity research out of Stanford and I guess with vegetables and fiber over time I can possibly increase my gut diversity again, develop that iron gut, and reverse the crazy MAST cell allergic-type reactions and poor health, fatigue, pain, etc. But if lack of gut biodiversity isn't a problem for you, hopefully just reduce endocrine disruptors around you and your body will clean out the persistent organic pollutants (POPs) like BPA, etc. eventually :)   I'm healing and I wish the same for you! So excited for the day I can eat vegan again. üôèü§ç

Hello guys! Bec... when I was 7-8 y/o I was diagnosed with leukemia and I had to go through a 2 year treatment, fast forward I'm now 24 years old and in remission for more than 10 years, I just wanna say that I was introduced to your channel for the travel content and I was like really happy watching you both, you became one of my favorite youtubers, and then when I saw your diagnosis video I bawled with you, I have not missed a single video, I know it's not the same but I know how it feels, please don't start thinking about what could've make you sick, it just... happens I remember and even now I'm like... why me? It's extremely rough on us and on the ones we love, my rock was my mom and I'm beyond happy that yours is Eamon and all your family and friends. I really love how you are taking all of this and also love how you are showing the good amd the bad. Please know that I'm here for you even if it's just by watching your videos. And know that you're not alone. Some tips that helped me through it are taking a lot of cranberry juice (even though I hated it lol), they told me that it helped the immune system recover because the chemo will take it hard on it, always getting chewing gum for all the times that chemo makes you throw up and if I remember any more know that I'll tell you. And of course it's okay to cry, it's more than okay to get mad and to scream because it's rough it really is so don't ever just keep it to yourself. Love you guys ‚ù§ Eamon you are literally goals. I'm glad you found each other.
Hey Guys, sending you all the love from the uk. I‚Äôve been where you are, I was diagnosed with leukaemia at 18. It‚Äôs an emotional rollercoaster for sure, with so many conflicting emotions all the time. My attitude towards cancer (most days) was to laugh through it and just get on with it, because I had no choice, so why mope? This made everyone think I was crazy, or unfeeling, or that I didn‚Äôt understand the gravity of the situation. Everyone handles it differently, and every day feels different. Don‚Äôt let anyone make you think you‚Äôre handling it wrong, there‚Äôs no right way. I love that your doctor acknowledged Eamon, it‚Äôs so hard to watch your loved ones be terrified for you. You‚Äôve got this, and in the future you will look back and think ‚ÄúI did that!!‚Äù. Best wishes x

First, I am so proud of the both of u as u bravely walk through this together, it cant b done alone so just know the bond u have together will c help get u to the finish line as far as the chemo goes.  Second, I am a hard core believer in our bodies ability to literally heal itself. About 10 yrs ago I was having dental issues with what I thought were abcesses top right area of my mouth. After multiple dentist visits, several extractions, several different rounds of antibiotics a biopsy finally taken and came back with FOLICULAR LYMPHOMA, a form of NonHodgkins Lymphoma. Mind u I suffered more than a year with daily horrible pain before I sought help since I thought it was horrible infection, swallowing was just a nightmare full of horrific pain, nothing at all helped that pain. When I finally found what I had I was sent to an Oncologyst set up treatment plan, had the appointment all within 1 day and had a week to deal with the what ifs etc.  I recall telling myself constantly, in my head repeating and directing myself in a way to take the Lymphoma out of my body, to make myself work hard for its own survival. Literally every second I was looping demands on my body to heal and remove the cancer wanting so badly to have faith in myself but also knowing part of me did not believe in any positive ending. The day for my first treatment was here and I "bravely" sat waiting for the doctor. He came in and wanted to do his planning etc to ensure the perfect area was all good. I opened my mouth, he was looking poking and said its gone!! I in shock asking what he was talking about he again said, "Its Gone!" The mass and area effected was suddenly, magically clear. I was sent for xrays to b sure and 100% it was truely gone. I had proof (I believe) that my constant direction to my innerself actually healed itself. There was nothing else done other than the constant inner speaking since the doctor agreed with me nothing to disprove it I felt proud to go home and trll my family the miricle of my self healing. Sorry it is a long story but Im hoping its worth the length if it gives u a positive outlook on something u can do that takes no time away from anything else ur doing, its free and if gives u a miricle even a little one to cast the cancer out of ur body or ease ur situation at all its worth a try.  I have come to honestly love u both so so much and Im grateful for allowing all of us to walk through this with u both. I wont say that I know one way or the other how this all turns out mainly it helps √±obody except the one saying it, I will say I am fighting for u both and with u both all the way and Im praying daily for u both and have started today to go to church and light two candles daily until ur told u KICKED CANCERS AS*!! I LOVE AND PRAY FOR U BOTH.

I thought I would pass along something I learned from another Youtube channel "The Frey Life." They use a free app called "abridge" to record all of their doctor's appointments. It's an app that was created by a cardiologist for his patients because often when you're in an appointment, so much medical jargon is covered, and so, so much is potentially forgotten. After you're done recording, it takes the recording and transcribes it to written word, while at the same time highlighting all the medical terms. This allows you the option to re-listen to the appointment, read what was said or you can click on the terms to just listen to those parts. Blessings and Love

FRESH Ginger, Turmeric, and lemon is a natural healing and cleansing boon to keep candida (or yeast) from developing throughout your whole system. Kombucha and prebiotics will be huge in maintaining a healthy gut and keep your sinuses from developing the unbalance of yeast that causes your throat, mouth, and sinus cavity to have issues. Turmeric is a natural anti-inflammatory. Ginger and lemon cleanse the throat and gut. Kombucha replaces the healthy bacteria. Chemo strips your body of everything. My first round I developed thrush and gut ache and the natural probiotic infusions were huge. I went the natural way during my rounds and it made a world of difference. üôè sending you all positive karma.

Beautiful video, you guys are super strong and your positivity is inspiring. There is one thing I really wanted to mention, in this video and the last one I could not help but notice that you guys mentioned not using a microwave anymore, obviously this is your choice and I‚Äôm not sure if the concern is related to plastic containers leeching anything into food when heated, but the kind of radiation that microwaves use is non-ionising radiation; a type of radiation that has enough energy to move atoms around within a molecule but not enough to remove electrons. The non-ionising radiation used in microwave ovens is not powerful enough to transfer radiation into food; it can only cause the water molecules to move. This is not a type of radiation that causes DNA damage.

Beck, I don‚Äôt know if you will see this, but please look at the connection between soy and estrogen based cancers. Soy is very very bad for women that are estrogen dominant. I have to stay away from it completely because my estrogen levels skyrocket and I get hormone tested A LOT. If I give my body the slightest bit of outside estrogen my levels go way high. I am also at risk for estrogen based cancers. Bless you, Beck. You CAN get through this.

Aloha honey just want to say my husband went through heavy chemotherapy hydrate your body with a gallon of water almost before you go in and get your treatment and then rinse it out of your body try to drink a gallon after you want it to get out of your system and not linger in your system that‚Äôs what will make you nauseated he never got sick one time the whole five month treatment. Also use your own bathroom. You do not want it to affect anybody elseRinsing that crap out of your system you will be fine remember drink water and hydrate all your cells before your treatment and then after your treatment.As soon as you can get that out of your system you will feel better. No relation to them, just amazed how much scientists actually know nowadays and appreciating someone explaining these newest findings of neurobiology in a simple enough manner. Maybe in a tough day it helps to shift the focus and you can find something that helps you.  Wouldn't want to overwhelm anyone with tips in this situation, just felt sharing that one simple yet amazing trick for the body and mental health is getting as much as daylight into our eyes as possible or at least substitute it with bright enough artifical light. You can just open a window if not feeling going out and leave the sunglasses home when you do go out, these small things help. Chemo was the hardest part of my cancer journey. I did three different rounds. I thought it would kill me. I was soooooo sick and sooooooo week. It was hard. VeRY hard. Still, I am grateful for the journey and the hard times because they gave me a very different outlook on life and my role in life. This is transformational.  Let the change happen.
My daughter has always had long, thick, beautiful hair. She has 2 sons and 1 daughter. When her daughter was 11 (3 years ago) she came to her mother and talked to her about ‚ÄúLocks of Love‚Äù. She wanted to donate her hair (also super long and thick) to help kids who had lost their hair to chemo/childhood cancer. Her Mother was so proud of her. Then she said, ‚ÄúMommy, would you please do this with me? Just think of how happy some child will be when they get YOUR hair!‚Äù They hugged and cried for a while. Last week my daughter was told by a new friend of hers that she has stage 3 Cancer. She had just started chemo and her hair has started falling out. Last night my daughter came in to me‚Ä¶.. completely bald. She wants to be there for her friend in every way possible. Just thought I‚Äôd share a hair story with you Bec. Just wanted to say...somethings just happen...6 years ago my husband had cancer and some days he wished he could die...he had radiation and chemo...he beat cancer and had been cancer free for 6 years...life was normal after that...both working and at the point getting ready for Christmas...Saturday Dec 18 was a normal day...ate supper and watched a movie...he woke up in the middle of the night saying he could not breath. Took him to emergency and they sent him home saying it was pneumonia...let‚Äôs just skip forward. Had to call the ambulance to come get him...he was later transferred back to the hospital that sent him home...he was diagnosed with GBS and was put on a ventilator that night. So since that night 11 pm Dec 19, 2021 he has not been able to talk, breath or move...it is 2 months today...I will never have him back the way he was...so sometimes bad things just happen...this GBS can happen to anyone at any time. My world has forever changed and I grieve for the loss of the man and the life we had planned. I am a bit better now...but still have good and bad days.

I know every recommendation is different but one thing I do want to ask you guys to ask your doctor about - when my mom went through chemo for BC she was told to not use vitamins or eat too many healthy foods because she was told you actually want to break down your immune system, not support it. So she would avoid too many foods with high amounts of vitamins, minerals and anti-oxidants. And then after chemo she would start eating very healthy again. My cousin was told the same thing during chemo for Hodgkins Lymphoma so I just wanted to mention it since I do see you focus on eating healthy alot. Sending you so much love and healthy vibes! Xx

A friend to walk and talk with Eamon when Bec resting  and u need to get stuff of ur chest and outta of ur head. I have had many years of ill health and struggling just now we had to put my dog to sleep and house no longer felt complete. I was no more dogs as I am mainly bed confined or when on rare occasions out in wheelchair. My husband was never a pet person but I came with animals lol... he has seen my sadness and was ok  if right dog comes along I will do all walks and u do all the snogs and cuddles. Well 2 weeks ago on a Friday dog charity we got our last dog from happened to send out email to all previous adopters saying service beginning to return to pre Covid working and there on the site a beautiful 6.5 year old Black Standard Poodle who previously lived with cats... We have 2 old ladies and needed a dog that likes cats ... I called and as we are known to them the quickest adoption ever 4 days, later this Shetland Pony size Goofball has joined our home and fitted in perfectly the gentle giant lives on my bed and on sofa and gives beautiful cuddles even my husband besotted and now going out again walking and yes giving cuddles, as well.  I thank previous owner for acknowledgement she could no longer cope with big dog and made right choice to re home. Piper brings such joy into our life.  My aim is to even get out into garden to sit and play ball even if freezing cold I will warm up. Bec and Eamon this will be a bumpy road but as you both have found there is, always a spark of joy and all else fails u can not beat a dog snog and cuddle. X
Good thing you kept sharing your life. Remember this type of cancer is NOT caused by the way you live or what you eat. It's just a couple of cells which had a plan of their own. Everybody has those cells, but they don't always succeed in their plan to take over the entire body.  Times will be hard, you will feel very sick after treatments, but there are also day's you feel better. Try to keep in shape and keep on weight. Eamon has a very difficult time to keep giving love as much as he can, without knowing how you feel. I can feel a good vibe between you two and Eamon is a very loving person. Let him know and feel loved too.  By the way, don't underestimate your dog, he is probably feeling better how you feel than you yourself. Let him comfort you and play with him when he thinks it is good for you.  Enjoy company and love. Love is the most important factor in being able to get healthy again.

And the weirdest thing for me was when my hair grew back in it came in curly and I've never had curly hair in my entire life I don't know how to cut it I don't know how to style it but  that maybe a blessing.... If I can suggest one thing is to get a lot of ginger root you can find it in the vegetable aisle the root itself you cut three chunks of it do not peel it and put it in a cup of water put in the microwave oil for 2 to 3 minutes and don't take the ginger it out cuz it'll start to get stronger and you sip on it and that will help with the nausea tremendously plus whatever they give you so the worst part is probably the fatigue and the nausea so do whatever you can to keep that under control and you'll do great love and prayers for you both and love fromUtah

An allegory: in precious metal forging there is an essential process called anealing. As the metal is hammered it becomes resistant, the molecular bonds tighten and if you keep going, it will crack. So, what you do is heat the metal cherry red and quench it in water. The bonds soften and relax; it then takes shape readily and easily. It moves toward becoming what it is meant to be.       I think of that in tough times, times of feeling in the fire. You, and Eamon are precious and you are becoming more despite how diminished you feel. Also every body is different and experience things differently but a lil trick I‚Äôve seen work with hair loss is kinda gross but in the two ppl I‚Äôve got to try it has actually worked or their body just did well but one was 72!! Don‚Äôt wash your hair at all or only once a month during chemo don‚Äôt brush it often honestly just braiding it and leaving it along is best but don‚Äôt let it get knotted(rats nest) just comb softly!! This sounds crazy but anything is worth a shot and like I said the ppl I‚Äôve seen do this didn‚Äôt lose much of their hair at all it got very thin but no bald spots or anything! The 72 didn‚Äôt wet or wash all through chemo and saw best results she did have some scans we took care of as needed and they healed up with no hair loss!

Great job #Bec!!!!!!. This is fantastic that you are sharing. I was diagnosed 12/2019 at 64,  I had the same drug as you for first 4 chemos, mine were two weeks apart as well. Then on to a different cocktail for 4 more. I could not do anything for 3 days after, and then got a little better everyday. I used to do laps in the house because my legs would get restless. I had genetic testing as well, didn't show anything. One of the hardest parts is the question why because you want to know how to keep it from coming back. I think very few people find out why. I never did, and like the geneticist said, you didn't do anything to cause it. The oncology nurses were the absolute best! They really helped me the most in managing the symptoms.

So glad you posted today, you have been on our mind a lot!  I have a recommendation.   On YouTube there‚Äôs a audio reading by Beverly Volfie , of ‚ÄúThe Long Winter‚Äù by Laura Ingalls Wilder.   Even tho it is a book geared to young adults, it remains one of my most favorite books that makes me feel super grateful for every little thing. It‚Äôs always worth another listen..Just a suggestion of course.üòämeanwhile we are sending you the healing good vibes and strength & courage ! And we are sending your Hubby  and family the same!!   Like my friend Marcia always says ‚Äú ‚Äú Pin on a grin and POWER THROUGH!!‚Äù And she also says if ya can‚Äôt grin in the moment ,  you just tell yourself to POWER THROUGH!
So, I'll share this with you....   I was paralyzed for almost 24 hours, I wedged my newborn between my body and couch to guarantee he did roll over and hurt. My boyfriend came home called the ambulance.  It was near death, doctors and nurses in emergency told me, If I waited a little longer, I would have died from a stroke from muscle and organ failures.  Luckily,  all my organs are safe.  I spent 5 days of painful tests, blood test at hospital.  I was diagnosed with a rare no cure desease that is life threatening and almost guaranteed.  I was put on 2 esteroids therapies systems simultaneously, that was sooooo excruciating painful and nauseating, no one understood me.  The pain is like no other, noone understands that there are days, so physically painful, you just want to rest.   And if that was the case, I would have downgraded my health 1000000%.  But,  my son has saved my life and kept me alive, because, I'm a fully stay at home mom, dedicated every second of the day for everything.  I had to stay agile for my son because my boyfriend works for us.  I had no choice but to continue being a 100000000% hands on mom, zero help, only when my bf came home.  No matter how sick and in pain I felt, I had to breastfeed, play, change diapers, love, cook, clean, work and everything under the son.  Lost some hair, gained some weight and was highly agetated 24/7.  I was under close administration and hundreds of blood tests and abnormal amounts of doctors appointments to prevent me from ending up in the hospital again, i landed a total of 3 times in 18 months.  I finally got off all the esteroid drugs therapies 4 months ago and I now I am feeling 1000%  dropped some pounds, I feel back to myself 90% and feeling good and happy.    For me, having my own private space was essential to recovering.   My inherited dease is DERMATOMYOSITIS, I have accepted my luck, embraced it enough to be aware and accepting this is my life and journey, I've never done drugs, nor marijuana, and consumed at most 25 alcohol beverages my entire life and I will 47 this month, I eat healthy, was pescatarian for 7 years, I eat everything now.  But the greatest thing I did for me to keep my spirit and happiness alive,  was to ignore that I have this, I dealt day by day, I have bags of my hair loss, I had little time to think about me.  It was a rough journey.  Off the meds, I am happier than ever.  And, my boyfriend did become my my 24/7 doctor and nurse. So many are not lucky like us.  We are blessed.     And I am so happy you both have each other through this new journey together, to add to your collection of memories.  And, for sure having your gorgeous dog is like having a child, and this is very positive for your journey, keep agile, keep positive and champion strong and focused.  Bea happy!  It all gets better sooner that you might anticipate.  Having an awesome support team is valuable.  Love you guys!

Hi Eamon & Bec. I'm not sure if this will get read/be received well. I've been following you guys for a several years and after being vegan for 6 years, walked away from veganism in 2021 for the sake of my health. When you understand more about how the human body *actually* functions, what it needs to thrive, bioavailability, iron poisoning, learning that the soil has been depleted for decades and thus all the vegetables being consumed are depleted as well (regardless of being organic.) Learning about how minerals "run the show" and you're not getting those minerals from being plant based. The idea that being plant based is healthy is one I had to reconsider when I stopped and said "if I'm so healthy, why am I having these health issues?" sure, I get that some things are out of our control, but I hope this can maybe plant a seed and you will consider reintroducing quality animal products, maybe even local so as to not contribute to factory farming. I have seen so many times long term vegans ending up with a plethora of health issues, and seeing their health do a complete 180 after eating animal products again. It isn't an easy decision, it's a complete paradigm shift. But we are animals a part of this food chain too. We are meant to eat meat. It isn't inherently the animal products that cause cancer/heart disease/etc that vegan propaganda says, how the animal was raised/fed matters a LOT. The idea that eating a soy/canola oil based impossible burger with 30 synthetic ingredients is healthier than eating a 1 ingredient grass fed burger is backwards. Remember, it's not only more profitable for industrial animal agriculture to raise and slaughter animals the way they do, it's even more profitable for them to sell meat alternatives with extremely cheap/unhealthy ingredients. But even if you didn't eat those things, we really do need animal products to properly nourish our bodies. This goes without saying I think but this is not an attack.. I genuinely care about true health and vitality. Please consider checking out the work of Morley Robins, Ray Peat, Matt Blackburn, even scroll through @GrimHood on twitter. Check out Mitolife Radio podcast. I wish you all the best and hope for a speedy recovery. <3

Hi Bec. I'm not sure if the genetic testing included MTHFR gene variation. I am BRCA2+ and choose prophylactic bilateral mastectomies at 32 and then had reconstruction. What I was not told about or informed of is the risk to #breastimplantillness which also includes a risk to a rare lymphoma. It seems the MTHFR gene causes a much higher risk of breast implant illness. Please please please search this. I have been ill for 5 years with the last 2 before my explant surgery the worst. I ended up bedridden, couldn't use my hands, was in chronic pain. It was awful. Take care and I wish you all the health and stamina for your journey ahead.
Love and hugs to you both. Thanks for sharing your journey. ü§ó

Cancers are fueled by glucose.  Eating carbs(fed state) that raise blood sugar is like adding gasoline to a fire. When in a fasted state the body turns to ketone bodies for fuel which starve the cancer. Desperate times call for desperate measures. The water fast is the most extreme "Keto" diet. The body is fueled by its own fat reserves primarly and harvests its own protein for the small trickle of sugar required  to keep you alive during the fast. That harvesting(autophagy) follows a very beautiful order and takes the garbage of the body first which includes cancers. This is how a fast can starve and even consume a cancer.

I‚Äôm only 18, but I have seen so much in this world, good and bad. When I was 14, my grandad (one of the people I loved most in the world) was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer. He was only 64. He suffered beautifully for a year until a bout of pneumonia got him in the end. It‚Äôs such a clich√© to say that he kept his smile until the very end, but he really did. He had this thick English accent and a never ending bucket of dad jokes, and he loved me so much. I never got to say goodbye, I don‚Äôt even remember the last thing I said to him, even giving the eulogy at his funeral didn‚Äôt give me much closure. But I was only a child and had to mature so quickly, I hated the world for so long after he left, I still do some days, it all seems so unfair. But part of me maturing is realising that the world is neither fair or unfair, it just is. It can be so cruel and so beautiful. I prayed to whatever deity would listen when he went into the hospital that, if he was suffering, he would die quickly and painlessly, like falling asleep. And that‚Äôs what he did, he passed out until his heart gave in. Some part of me knew when he went into that hospital that he wasn‚Äôt going to come out. Sometimes I think he heard my prayer and knew it was okay to leave. I know I didn‚Äôt kill my grandfather, cancer did, but maybe he heard me and knew I‚Äôd be okay eventually; or maybe he just did what a lot of people with cancer do and died. I won‚Äôt ever know. But what I do know is that he loved me soooooo much and won‚Äôt ever stop even though he‚Äôs gone, and I‚Äôll always love him too. The world seemed cruel for taking him away from me, but now I realise it gave him to me in the first place. I only got him for 14 years, but what a brilliant 14 years it was. He lives on in the stories my family tells, in my memories and in the picture of him and his wonderful grin that I keep on my bedside table. I‚Äôm still young and not at all wise, but I urge you to see the beauty in the world, and to keep hope alive. It‚Äôs all any of us have sometimes, but it‚Äôs enough.
